PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. On the assessment of the government, what proportion of Australian land might be the subject of native title claim, what analysis has been done by the government on this matter, and will the government table any such analysis?
—Potentially all of it. What's the point of the question? Anyone can slap in a claim. It is a question of whether it succeeds or not.

—I endorse the comments of Senator Collins in that respect. A claim can be made about anything. Whether it succeeds is the question. The truth of the matter is that so far as freehold title is concerned there is no question of any claim being sustainable. So far as leasehold titles are concerned, the High Court decision makes it absolutely clear, for land in respect of which valid leases have been issued in times past, that there is no credible basis on which it could be believed other than that native title is extinguished.

PARA.TAB: For claims made in respect of leasehold land where there is some reason to believe that the grant of title might conceivably have been invalid—as I said yesterday, that is only a tiny percentage of all the leasehold interests that have been granted in this country—the legislation will make it perfectly clear that the validation procedure carries with it the extinguishment of any such claim to native title. The only residual native title that will be able to be claimed in respect of land which has already been alienated in the past, whether by way of freehold or leasehold, will be in respect of leasehold interest that is vested in Aboriginal people in situations where, as has been announced, they themselves can establish a properly based claim to native title. Under those circumstances there is an option for native title to be vested in them.

That is the context in which the question is being asked and that is my response. Only a very tiny percentage of interests have been granted in the past in respect of which an even faintly credible prima facie case could be made for a claim to be initiated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. With respect to the minister, I do not think his response answers the question. Obviously what we are talking about is the government's assessment as to whether there is a credible basis of claim. If the government is to implement new legislation to deal with native title, it would have made an assessment, one would have thought, as to what part of Australia would be potentially capable of such claim.
—Stupid!

—I am astounded to hear that the answer seems to be `Of course not'. As Senator Collins said, potentially all of Australia could be capable of such a claim. Has the government made an assessment as to what part of the country over which there is a credible basis for claim? If the government has made such an assessment, will it table it?

—The question is based on a completely false premise. The only thing that is clear about the question is the determination of the opposition to mount a continuing exercise in scaremongering. It has not contributed in any positive way to the consideration of this public policy issue at any stage during the process. Its approach has been that of opportunists and scavengers and it does not deserve to be given a sensible answer when it asks questions like that. Of course, we can give those opposite information—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Standing orders clearly provide that no minister is entitled to make personal reflections, and to describe people as `scavengers' is typical of the way in which those opposite handle these debates. Mr President, I invite you to direct the minister to provide a sensible and considered answer to the question.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—That is the key question, you idiot!
—I think the word `scavenger' should be withdrawn, but so should the word `idiot'.
—I can keep `opportunist' then, can I, Mr President? I withdraw `scavengers'.
—Will you withdraw, Senator Kemp.
—It was a fair question as to what proportion of Australia could be claimable. To say that that was not a fair question is absurd.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. My question relates to the government's budget, particularly the longer term strategy implicit in that budget. Would the minister advise what evidence there is of the priority which the international financial community accords to the government's medium term budget strategy in making its assessments of Australia's economic outlook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston raises a very important issue. It actually goes to something seriously pursuing Australia's national interest instead of merely trying to scaremonger about something that is fundamentally important but which is not understood.

PARA.TAB: In this context, I recently had a meeting with representatives of various members of the financial community, including a senior executive from a German bank. He was discussing European and international financial community reaction about investment. He said that no-one in the international financial community was talking about the investment uncertainty flowing from Mabo—after all, many European countries are having to deal with similar issues after the collapse of the Iron Curtain. However, he emphasised that the international financial community is talking about the uncertainty flowing from the obstruction in the Senate of the government's medium term deficit reduction strategy.

An Australian bank representative at the same meeting, who had recently returned from Europe, said exactly the same—that that was the question being asked; it was not about Mabo, notwithstanding the attempt to whip up uncertainty, which the Australian people have seen through, as has the international community. The opposition continues to be irresponsible in its attitude about medium term deficit reduction strategy and tries to pretend that there is no economic downside to what it is proposing to do.

Let me make it very clear that this irresponsibility does matter. It matters in a way that directly affects every Australian. For example, on 8 October a representative of Moody's warned of serious consequences for the Australian dollar, interest rates and the country's credit rating if the budget impasse continues much longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dollar is rising.

—Yes. They have got faith in the government; that is true. The dollar and the stock market are rising. Those opposite used to say that when those things went down it was bad for the government; the fact that they are going up shows what positive attitudes they have towards the government. Senator Kemp is quite correct.

PARA.TAB: But the IMF has said that it is very important that governments everywhere acknowledge that the re-emergence of large budget deficits would be a cause of great concern—I am paraphrasing there—and a failure to reduce substantially these imbalances over the medium term would likely cause renewed upward pressure on long-term interest rates, reduce capital formation and the scope for new job creation in the private sector, lower the rate of growth of potential output and income, and continue to impede the flexibility of fiscal policy in the event of adverse cyclical developments. It went on to say further:

ANSWER.PARA: As recent experience in several countries shows, early announcement and legislation of credible medium term deficit reduction measures have immediate beneficial effects on long term interest rates and on economic confidence, even when recessionary conditions make it difficult to undertake significant deficits in the short run.
. . . postponing action to deal with the fiscal imbalances would continue to impede a recovery of confidence.

I welcome the fact that the opposition recognises that the stock market, consumer confidence and the dollar are all going up. All those are significant pluses for the economy, just as it is a plus that we are growing faster than any other country in the Western world; all those things are pluses. But it is not an excuse for irresponsibility. It is not an excuse for trying to undermine the medium-term deficit reduction strategy which is fundamental to the long-term economic success of this country. The opposition's irresponsible approach puts in grave danger the job creation priorities that the medium-term deficit reduction strategy makes possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Following his failure to answer Senator Hill's question in relation to native title, could he tell the Senate, firstly, what are the rights attached to native title under the government's proposed legislation and, secondly, what are the special benefits and protections referred to by the Prime Minister which will be extended to native titleholders?

—The characteristics of native title are those that have been spelt out in the discussion paper and in the paper that has been circulated—and there has been no suggestion of any change in that respect. The title conveys a capacity to occupy the land in question and, in other contexts, it might savour of equivalents of hunting and fishing rights and things of this kind.

PARA.TAB: One way of describing native title is to say that it is like a deck of cards, in a sense, with a number of different components in it, depending on the context. But the particular context that seems to trouble the opposition is the effectively exclusive occupancy characteristic of native title in respect of particular tracts of land. So far as that is concerned, the position is as we have described it: that native title right will have to be established through the court system. It will then have to run the gauntlet of a process in the state court and tribunal system in determining the economic uses to which the land in question, the subject of the established native title claim, can be put. Whether those uses are mining uses or other kinds of uses will be a matter for determination by the relevant state and territory tribunals.

There will be certain consequences that flow from particular kinds of uses being allowed for particular kinds of native title land. There will be compensation consequences in some contexts; there will be other kinds of non-monetary compensation remedies or compensation available in other contexts. It is impossible to succinctly summarise what the particular residual content of the native title will be after it has run the gauntlet of all those processes. It depends on the particular process that is adopted and the particular result of that process in the particular context.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, you don't know.

—There is an element of stupidity demonstrated by some of those who interject in this chamber, Mr President, that is so supreme and so comprehensive that it is very difficult to respond in an intelligent way.
—Order! Senator Alston, you are constantly interjecting.

—The short point, I think, that needs to be made in all of this is: where does the opposition stand on this particular issue? What is its position? Does it have any principles at all? Is it bringing to bear any concept of justice in this matter? Is it bringing to bear any concept of the balance that it is necessary to draw between competing interests?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on relevance. The question from Senator Campbell was very clear. It asked what were the special benefits and rights attached to native title. Senator Evans has to turn his mind to that question rather than constantly abusing the opposition.

—Further to the point of order, given the level of interjections and points made by those opposite, Senator Evans is entitled to test their credibility on this issue. The fact that they have no policy on Mabo is entitled to be discussed here.
—Order! There is no point of order. There are certain members of the opposition who are constantly interjecting. I ask them to cease.

—I continue to make the point that if those opposite are going to respond as strenuously as they have, they do need to show some responsibility of their own in contributing to the policy process. When I try to answer a question which, by its nature, is almost impossible to answer simply and straightforwardly with a response which points to the complexity of the issue and the fact that the process itself will determine the content of the right, I am met with nothing but jeering of the ignorant. Under those circumstances, I think those opposite have been given a better answer than they deserve.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his attempt to answer the first part of the question, but I ask him to turn his mind to the second half of it, which is to define—and it should not be so hard to define—the special benefits and protections the Prime Minister referred to in his statement. I would also like the minister to turn his mind to whether those special benefits and protections are the subject of article 1(4) of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

—The special benefit and protection that is essentially provided by this legislation is the recognition of the right of native people who can establish the necessary connection with the land to have this compendious concept, which I have tried to describe, of native title, which in some contexts will involve, effectively, a complete freehold enjoyment and in other contexts something less than that.

PARA.TAB: The precise content of that title might be some sort of residual sliver of rights or, for example, perhaps some formally acknowledged recognition of what previously has been a common law right of occupancy, or a statutory reservation that has been granted to Aboriginal people in respect of some particular tract of land. It is possible in some contexts to imagine that being acknowledged now as a result of these processes as a form of native title. Beyond that, we are talking about the kind of interests that are enjoyed by ordinary non-Aboriginal people in respect of land in question given the nature of the particular interest that is involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Can the minister inform the Senate of plans for Australian defence assistance to Cambodia?

—Australia is committed to supporting the new government of Cambodia. We do intend to develop a modest bilateral defence relationship. We envisage a program of cooperative defence activities geared to meet Cambodia's needs, developed along lines similar to the programs we undertake with other regional countries. As far as practicable, our assistance will focus on expert and technical advice to help the Cambodians deal with their problems utilising their own resources.

PARA.TAB: Last month Australian defence officials visited Cambodia for discussions with Cambodian officials and outlined how Australia might be able to assist. As a result of these discussions, a three-man ADF team is currently in Cambodia studying the communications needs of the Cambodian Royal Armed Forces. This study is a logical flow-on from the major role our force communications unit played in providing the nation-wide UNTAC communication systems.

Another team will leave for Cambodia on 24 October to conduct a similar study of the Cambodian Royal Armed Forces maritime support system. Possible future assistance—depending, of course, on Cambodia's wishes—could include higher level management assistance to the Cambodian Mine Action Centre, malaria research support and English language training.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Is it correct that the government's new country of origin product labelling scheme will not require the country of origin of a product to be shown at all? Is it correct that under the new scheme it will be possible to label a food `Made in Australia' even if the majority of its ingredients are, in fact, imported?

—I do have some information for Senator Lees, but I am not sure that it goes precisely to the points that she raises. To the extent that it does not, I will agree to supply her with further information at a later time.

PARA.TAB: The government is very aware, as are the Democrats—but I am sure the opposition does not share the same concern—that consumers do want simple and reliable information to identify Australian goods. That is very much our starting point. It is not an easy area to tackle. One has to work through it with the agreement of and in consultation with state governments. After review, consultation and research, the Minister for Consumer Affairs has gained cabinet endorsement for a scheme that the government believes meets these demands.

The scheme is based on amending the Trade Practices Act to prescribe what terms have to be used when a good for sale in Australia makes a claim to be Australian. I do accept there is a distinction between that and the first part of Senator Lees's question. The scheme itself will provide a baseline for all such goods and relevant authorities will be able to build on it but not go below the provisions of the scheme. Food labelling is the responsibility of the National Food Authority which has recently released guidelines on the new scheme, once again, not going below it but building on it.

In circumstances where all major components originate in Australia and any processing has been done in Australia, the terms `product of Australia' or `produce of Australia' can be used. The term `made in Australia' can be used when some of the components have been imported but the product gained its essential character here. When the goods do not qualify for these two terms but some processing took place here, a term such as `blended' or `packed in Australia from imported goods' can be used. This is the general background and the structure of the scheme that has been adopted by the government.

Senator Lees's questions do go to some points quite pertinent to the answer I have given but, to a certain degree, the answer does not cover the proposition she puts forward. I will take those questions on notice and get further answers for her from the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. To be more precise, the problem is with that term `gained its essential character here'. Surely, in the interests of Australian farmers, it would be far better if the label read, `processed in Australia from imported product'.
—I think Senator Lees has given an example to demonstrate the first part of her question. I will, of course, take that on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I note this morning's media coverage on the review of the Office of the Status of Women which reports the minister as saying that the office will be refocussing its activities to concentrate on policy. How will this result in real advances for Australian women?

—Yes, it is true that yesterday I handed the report on the review of the Office of the Status of Women to the Prime Minister. That review makes it very clear that the principal recommendation for the outcome of the review and for the office is that it become, once again, principally focused on policy. The review also set three clear policy priorities and they are: economic security for women; public and political life, the effect of those and women's relation to them; and, women and the law, particularly looking at the impact of law relating to violence against women.

PARA.TAB: Under the heading of economic security, the principal subheadings are: employment, child care and superannuation. Superannuation, in particular, is something that many women have only just begun to get access to. It is also something that will be affected by the removal of the exemptions under the sex discrimination legislation. We want to be absolutely sure that women maximally benefit in terms of advantages and access to superannuation.

It is quite clear that the best of government depends on good policy. Good policy advice to cabinet and in the budget preparations is the way in which we can get the best outcome, particularly in this case, for the advantages of women of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've been saying that for a decade.

—Yes, we have been saying it and that is precisely why this government is where it is—because it has delivered on excellent policy and programs for women. So far there is no doubt at all that our child-care policies—to choose just one area—have been a watershed and a milestone in terms of the advantages and opportunities they have provided for women. How could the opposition not agree with that, or is it saying it does not?

PARA.TAB: It is also true that the Office of the Status of Women is the area of government that has put violence against women on the political agenda. That emerged out of an initiative by minister Tate to have an inquiry into violence, although much of the work, particularly in relation to the supply of shelters for women, has been done. But the main game in terms of highlighting violence against women and taking steps to address ways in which we can prevent it has very much been sheeted home to the Office of the Status of Women in the last five years.

This review, particularly with its emphasis on refocussing on good policy advice, is just the way we need to continue to go to improve and focus that policy so as to ensure that the advantages for women to this point are not lost but built on and developed. The other thing the review highlights is new and improved ways of consulting with the women of Australia. This is spelt out in the review document. That kind of consultation with women is vital; it is the sort of information that has meant that our programs for women have been relevant and targeted to the very immediate needs of women.

The consultation processes replace the National Women's Consultative Council with a committee designed particularly to work with non-government organisations and the government in preparation for the very significant United Nations conference on women to be held in Beijing in 1995. We have also established a program of round table consultation with women's organisations which will occur every six months. That will make a very considerable difference in the access of those organisations immediately to me, the minister, and to other ministers in the government.

Finally, we are increasing the operational grants to women's organisations. If we want those organisations to be increasingly professional and offer more significant advice to government, it is proper that we increase the operational grants to them. I think governments should be very appreciative of the review, its outcomes and the direction the office will now take.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to yesterday's Commonwealth Mabo response, particularly in relation to compensation and the proposed federal-state cost sharing arrangements.
—Tell us where you stand on it.

—Right here. Can the government give any indication of the likely total cost of compensation which might be payable? It is a pretty simple question; I thought Senator Gareth Evans could follow that one. Will the Commonwealth accept the full responsibility for compensation costs, at least prior to 31 December 1993 and, if not, why not? On what principles will any cost sharing formula with the states be based? Will the government rule out the need for the introduction of any new taxes or tax increases to meet the cost of compensation?

—As the Prime Minister's statement made perfectly clear, there will be further discussions with the states and territories on cost sharing arrangements in all the relevant contexts in which that issue might arise. I have nothing further to add on that part of the question.

PARA.TAB: Compensation is payable, of course, in the context of where existing grants have had to be validated by the operation of statute. That validation process does not result in any liability for compensation on the part of the actual lessees; it is a matter for government to pick up the tab. What the size of that tab will be is impossible to quantify at this stage, but our expectation is that the sum will be very small for exactly the reasons that I have spelt out previously.

In the case of valid grants, which are presumed to be the overwhelming majority of those that have been made in the past, no question of compensation will arise. Extinguishment, according to the High Court judgment, has been already accomplished. It does not need a statute to do that. The only context in which the statute has bite of its own and where compensation accordingly becomes payable is where there has to be a validation process occurring in order to correct some defect that the court might find.

As I said yesterday at great and nauseous length—and I hope I do not need to repeat it—it is our expectation that there will only be at best, if any, a tiny minority of cases where it will be able to be established that something in the nature of validation was required because the original grant was invalid. Post-1975 it is conceivable that a grant would have been invalid because of a failure to apply the principles applicable under the Racial Discrimination Act, but even that is highly arguable. And, of course, only a very small number of relevant leasehold interests have been granted since 1975 anyway.

Otherwise, before 1975, the argument becomes even more tenuous as to what the nature of a possible invalidation may have been. It has to be based on the existence of native title and some other law—presumably a law of fiduciary duty or something of that kind—in respect of which there is very little reason to believe that any plausible case will ever be able to be mounted. Against that background and that being the context in which compensation may be payable—although it is impossible to quantify, and will remain so in advance of the event—there is no reason whatsoever to believe that a large sum will be involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the minister's reference to there being, in his words, a very small amount involved. I did not ask for a precise figure; I asked for a ballpark estimate, a rough guess, some indication. Is the true position that he has no idea and that the government is about to embark upon a process with no idea of how much it will cost?

—I have nothing further to add to my answer, other than to draw attention once again to the utter inability and unwillingness of the opposition to make clear where it stands on these issues in any positive or constructive way. The one large missing factor in this equation is any demonstration of a responsible contribution by the opposition to this policy process. It has not put in in the past; it is not putting in now; and, on present evidence, it will not put in in the future. The Australian public will make its judgment accordingly.
—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, relates to the killing of four land rights protesters—
—Ask him something he knows something about.
—Senator Macdonald, it is probably the sort of solution that those opposite would like to suggest in respect of Mabo.
—Order! Ask the question.

—My question relates to the killing of four land rights protesters by the Indonesian security forces on the island of Madura in East Java. Can the minister inform the Senate what the government's response has been to those killings?

—We were very disturbed by the reports of those killings. I raised the Australian government's concern over the incident in Madura with my colleague Ali Alatas in New York a few days after the incident occurred. I am now very pleased to see and be able to advise the Senate—honourable senators may have seen some reports in the press about it this morning—that the Indonesian authorities have responded quickly and positively in a way which acknowledges the seriousness of that incident, which acknowledges that there was government responsibility for it, and which acknowledges that there is a need to take effective action against those who were directly responsible.

PARA.TAB: President Suharto has been quoted as saying a few days ago that incidents such as the one at Nipah dam should not happen again anywhere in the country. He has called for more effective consultation between authorities and local people to avoid misunderstandings. He has expressed his concern and promised that the government will take action against wrongdoers. Since that statement was made, the governor of East Java has publicly accepted full official responsibility for the incident.

More specifically, a few days ago the commander of the Indonesian armed forces, General Feisal Tanjung, stated that action would be taken against both the military and police personnel involved in the killings, as well as their superiors, because their actions were wrong and unprofessional. The East Java military commander has been reported as saying that four officers have now been removed from their duties and might face a military trial. Local police and military chiefs are among the four removed.

I am informed that a full official inquiry is now under way. It is therefore inappropriate to make further comment while investigation by the Indonesian authorities continues. But I make the point that, given the kinds of concerns that have been expressed in the past by these incidents that have occurred from time to time in various parts of the Indonesian archipelago, this is a welcome response by the Indonesian government. It shows that it is concerned about some of the things that have been going on and is willing to respond in a way that will satisfy international opinion, and rightly so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to the Prime Minister's Mabo statement in relation to pastoral leases issued before 1975 which are invalid on grounds unconnected with the Racial Discrimination Act but connected with some other right and his statement a couple of minutes ago which mentioned fiduciary duty. Does this mean all pastoral leases may be potentially open to challenge on these other legal grounds, or has the government assessed how many pastoral leases may be open to challenge on these grounds?

—The very nature of the grounds that have been mentioned here are such as to make them extremely unlikely to arise in practice. It is impossible to quantify that. One has to satisfy a series of criteria before one can even get to first base. First of all, one obviously has to have a credible native title claim in respect of the particular land in question by a current group of Aboriginal people who can establish the necessary connection with the land. That would exclude the overwhelming majority of leasehold interests around the country from even prima facie exposure to such claims.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, one has to have some kind of basis for suggesting that there was some breach of duty or some other legal principle offended in conjunction with the availability of native title in order to have given rise to some invalidation. The legislation that we are proposing—both the government's and that which we are inviting the states to enact, and I am sure they will—will result immediately in the up front, here and now validation of any such potentially invalid leases.

The effect of that legislation will be to remove any ground for concern so far as any individual leaseholder is concerned anywhere in the country. It is just conceivable that in some isolated cases nonetheless members of an Aboriginal group may decide that they think they have some basis on which to mount a claim. They can do that. They can make their claim in the courts. If in the extremely unlikely event—and every lawyer I have spoken to in the country takes the view that it is an extremely unlikely event—that they happen to succeed in that claim, then there would be a question, as I said earlier, of compensation arising. But again it is not something which would, in any way, affect the position of the leaseholder. It would be a matter for the government to provide.

What we are trying to do, if those opposite can begin to understand the concept and the theory that lies behind this, is put to rest any fears that might conceivably exist in this respect and to cover off and give certainty to all those particular areas where nonetheless it is just possible legally that some particular claim or action might be brought. We cannot legislate against people bringing claims, but we can legislate in a way to make it absolutely clear, in accordance with accepted principles, that there will not be any adverse consequences flowing from that—either the claim being made or even in the extremely unlikely event of that claim being upheld.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Prime Minister's statement says that the issuing government can validate these leases. Does this mean that the government must validate the leases, or does it have some discretion?

—If there is some state that is not minded, for whatever reason, to enact up-front legislation validating conceivably invalid leases, then the legislation will further provide, and this has been also made clear or will be made clear in the latest version of the detailed document that goes out, that it will be possible, after the event, to legislate in order to effectively validate a leasehold interest that has actually been declared by a court to be invalid for a native title reason. I think it is extremely unlikely and the government believes it is extremely unlikely that that situation will arise because it is to be naturally expected that states will want to legislate to remove any possible area of residual uncertainty in this respect. If they do not, the government's legislation will still make it clear that that situation can be covered off. So again there is no need to worry.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. During his forthcoming visit to Indonesia, is the Prime Minister intending to sign a joint Australian-Indonesian nuclear science cooperation treaty? What guarantees are there that this treaty will not involve Australia in the supply of uranium to Indonesia or the supply of nuclear science technology that may be used in the development of Indonesia's nuclear industry? What action has the Prime Minister taken to fulfil the commitment he made in his environment statement last year to prohibit the importation into Australia of radioactive waste of foreign origin?
—Mr President—
—Why don't you look at my question in the estimates committee?

—Senator Tambling did ask that question. It was one of his better questions; it did not have much to beat. It is not the case that the Prime Minister will sign any such treaty arrangement during his forthcoming visit to Indonesia. Discussions on the conclusion of the nuclear science and technology cooperation agreement are still taking place with Indonesia. The Indonesian minister for science and technology prefers that that nuclear cooperation agreement be signed in the context of a broader complementary science and technology agreement, and discussions on that general agreement are still in progress.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the second part of Senator Bourne's question, as I have previously stated, the proposed nuclear science and technology cooperation agreement will not provide for commercial transfers of Australian uranium to Indonesia. It does refer to the potential for such commercial transfers in the future. It notes that an appropriate nuclear transfers agreement would be necessary to enable such transfers to take place.

As I said in the Senate on 7 September, the nuclear science and technology cooperation agreement that is under discussion with Indonesia is, like most intergovernmental agreements of its kind, a framework agreement. While setting out the types of areas of intended cooperation, including nuclear safety issues, medical applications and so on, such agreements do not oblige either party to participate in particular projects. It is just a framework document. The proposed agreement is intended to enhance our cooperation with Indonesia in the nuclear area, but in such areas as it spells out: nuclear medicine, radiation protection, nuclear related safety information and technology, and applications of radio isotopes.

With respect to the last part of Senator Bourne's question, our policy does prohibit the disposal in Australia of other countries' radioactive wastes. That has been applied through the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, under which radioactive materials are listed in schedule B. Importation is not permitted unless authorised by the relevant minister. While we do intend to introduce legislation to prohibit absolutely the importation of high level radioactive wastes of foreign origin, we import a number of goods whose classification as radioactive or waste may be difficult to resolve.

The use of nuclear and radioactive techniques in modern economies occurs in areas as diverse as nuclear medicine, agriculture, water resource management, harbour siltation, biological studies and non-destructive testing of engineering works. All of these activities necessarily involve the production, transport and disposal of some degree of radioactive waste. It is in that context that we have to pick and choose our way fairly carefully through a legislative minefield. But the basic policy is clear and it has not changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Prime Minister's statement on the government's response to the High Court's decision on native title is notably light on concern and protection for our greatest export earner, the mining industry. Will exploration licences and mining leases have the same protection as claims for pastoral leases? Will extension of those licences and leases also be guaranteed? What government protection is envisaged, if any, to protect the mining industry from actions through a federal court, state court or tribunal designed to delay mining exploration and development?

—There is a whole complex of provisions in the proposed legislation, most of which were spelt out in outline and have not been changed since the original document was made public. Those provisions make very clear that, in the case of native title sought over existing areas the subject of mining operations and so on, title will be subject to all sorts of determinations and limitations that will ensure the continuity of the present operations. So far as title grants are made now in respect of land over which subsequent exploration or mining licences are sought, it will again be a matter of the relevant interests being weighed and balanced through the tribunal and court process that is being set up.

PARA.TAB: Basically, two streams of activity go on. One stream of activity is to determine the existence of the native title in the particular context, with the content of that title depending on the nature of the traditional association and all the rest of the things that have been spelt out in previous discussion papers. But the potential of other forms of economic activity nonetheless to take place, although that title has been acknowledged, will then depend on the second stream of determinations through the economic use tribunals, if I might so describe them, which will be essentially the existing mining wardens' courts in the present state.

It will be the state and territory tribunals that determine the economic uses, including mining uses of all kinds, to which the particular land, the subject of native title, can be put. Certain consequences flow from that in terms of rights of negotiation, compensation and all the rest of it, but that equally is determined by those tribunals. It will be perfectly possible for these various interests to coexist in that sense. It is for that reason that I think one will find that the final reaction of the mining industry to this package of legislation will be quite muted, if not indeed supportive. We will have to wait and see. It is always possible for scaremongering campaigns to be mounted in that context or any other, but the government is very conscious of the need to get this balance right between the national economic interest and the Aboriginal interest. That is one of the things we believe we have achieved with this legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think the minister's answer may add to the confusion that will abound within the mining industry. I am not saying that from any scaremongering point of view. The Prime Minister's statement quite clearly points out:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Bill will enhance the right of native title holders to negotiate on proposed actions which affect their land.

He then goes on to talk about the time limits. In the minister's previous capacity as minister for energy, he will appreciate the detail involved in the application for mining exploration areas and then going on to a lease. It seems to me, from reading the Prime Minister's statement, that in practice the minimum amount of time required for anyone seeking an exploration licence and then going on to get permission to develop a mine would be in the order of 18 months. That is before any other approvals can be sought. I just seek the minister's views on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —In many ways this is a matter that is more appropriate for the committee stage of the debate when we all have actual legislation in front of us rather than just general principles. The basic principle as to the right to negotiate was set out in the original public document. The relevant paragraphs make it clear that we are only talking about the few short months for that process of negotiation to work its way through—three or four months, or six months, as the case may be—with provision, of course, for extension by agreement between the parties on those basic limits.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, relates to the latest national road toll statistics for the nine months to September, which show 88 deaths fewer than the level at the same time last year—a drop of five per cent. Can the minister inform the Senate what action the federal government has been taking which may have assisted this encouraging trend? What strategies are planned for a continued reduction in road trauma?

—I thank Senator Zakharov for her question. I can confirm the encouraging downward trend in the national road toll for the first nine months of this year. By the end of September, 1,365 Australians had tragically died on our roads. The figure for the same period last year was 1,453—a drop of over five per cent. That is an extremely significant decline in road fatalities.
—More young men die from suicide than on the roads under your government.

—True as it is, I just do not understand the relevance of that, frankly. This continues the trend of recent years where in 1990 road deaths fell by 17 per cent over the previous year and a further nine per cent and seven per cent in the two subsequent years which I would have thought that Senator Herron, as a surgeon, would be welcoming rather than disparaging.

PARA.TAB: These figures are a dramatic improvement on the 3,800 fatalities recorded in 1970. A number of measures and events have contributed to sustained reductions in the road toll from that totally objectionable level in 1970. These have included the introduction of blood alcohol limits; the compulsory wearing of seat belts and motorcycle safety helmets introduced in the early 1970s; the introduction by most states of random breath testing in the early 1980s, which I think has made a very significant contribution, particularly, to change community attitudes to drink driving; the federal government's 10-point package of road safety measures adopted by all states and territories from 1989, which introduced uniform blood alcohol concentration levels and the compulsory wearing of bicycle helmets; significant improvements in vehicle safety design encouraged by ongoing development of motor vehicle standards by the federal government; and perhaps most importantly, a marked change in community attitudes to road safety which many of the initiatives that I have just mentioned had a role in forming.

The federal government has been encouraged by the positive trends in reducing road trauma for Australians. It is continuing to work toward an even safer road environment by working with other governments, industry and community groups. This cooperative approach has resulted in the development for the first time, I might add, of a national road safety strategy setting out eight major objectives toward a target of reducing road deaths to the level of 10 per 100,000 of the population by the year 2001 when, of course, we will be a republic and have our own flag.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are like Pavlov's dogs; just ring a bell and they salivate. If the community can meet these objectives it will help save between 3,000 and 4,000 lives and up to 150,000 casualties over the next 10 years.

PARA.TAB: Today I attended the annual conference of the National Road Trauma Advisory Council in Canberra to release for public comment the draft national road safety action plan. I commend to those senators who do have an interest in road safety the strategy action plan, copies of which I will be happy to provide to any senators. I will welcome any suggestions they might have to either myself or the federal office of road safety for further improvement in the continuing reduction of these unfortunate statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister on Mabo affairs.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —An event of national importance is declared only for events of great significance to the whole nation. It will be one of the most significant commemorative events in the history of the War Memorial, since it opened on Armistice Day in 1941.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister's declaration means that the ABC will provide a national telecast and national radio coverage of the event and that it will make its telecast available to other carriers in Australia without charge. This provides the greatest possible opportunity for all Australians to become involved in this commemoration.

In the lead-up to the events of 11 November, the remains of an unknown Australian soldier from the First World War are to be exhumed in France and they will be returned to Australia early next month. After lying in state at old Parliament House, the remains will be entombed in the Hall of Memory at the Australian War Memorial at 11 a.m. on 11 November, marking the 75th anniversary of the end of the Great War.

Veterans of that conflict will be present to see their former comrade reburied with honour, as will a large number of veterans of the Second World War, the Korean and Vietnam wars. Other representatives of federal, state and territory governments, the Defence Force chiefs, the vice-chairman of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission, the mayors of Villers-Bretonneux in France and Ypres in Belgium and representatives of national veterans and war widows organisations have all been invited to take part in the procession and in the funeral service.

Ceremonies in some places, such as Dubbo, Launceston, Sale and Albany, are receiving support from the War Memorial for a range of community activities to reflect the special significance of this event. TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to reports in today's media that the government is considering establishing a special scheme which will provide permanent residence to Cambodian boat people who are in their fourth year of detention if they first return to Cambodia. Are these reports accurate; and why is the government announcing this program at this time, given the current inquiry by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration which is examining Australia's detention practices and which is due to report in December?

—The reports in substantial part are correct. The government has decided to make available a number of places under the special assistance category program as part of our humanitarian program, and to make those available for people who will be able to apply for entry to Australia from Cambodia.

PARA.TAB: The basic point is that the government will maintain the integrity of both the immigration program and the SAC program by insisting that people who apply to come here, first, will be in Cambodia when they apply and will have been there for some 12 months before being eligible to apply under the SAC program and, secondly, will be sponsored by family or close links within Australia. In terms of those close links, the government will provide that community based organisations such as churches will be able to qualify to sponsor those people who do apply from Cambodia.

This program is at the moment running at some 6,300 strong; it applies in compassionate circumstances to people from a number of countries. I think the biggest intake under this program now comes from former Yugoslavia. But the Cambodian SAC recognises that the Cambodian people have suffered hardship due to the political and social turmoil over recent years, and that that hardship has denied them the educational and social development that may have enabled them to obtain the qualifications required under our family reunion program. The SAC package is a compassionate response to their plight.

I do stress that it is not geared solely towards those who may have been in detention for a number of years; it is a package which is made available to those in Cambodia, in compassionate circumstances, with links in Australia and for whom those links will provide settlement assistance for the first six months in terms of food, clothing and other social support assistance.

In developing this particular package, the government has also kept in mind not only the need to ensure that those who come here illegally do not have the power to access avenues of staying here from within Australia—which is why we are insisting that those who do qualify under this package will have to apply from within Cambodia—but also to recognise that the SAC program has been used extensively in respect of a number of countries to provide for these compassionate circumstances.

As I said earlier, that program is running at 6,300 strong this financial year. The 40, 50 or so whom we expect to qualify under this program from Cambodia this financial year will come from within that 6,300. We anticipate that this number will go up to about a couple of hundred in the following financial year, but once again they will come from within the special assistance category package.

In deciding that only those who are within Cambodia can apply to come to Australia for permanent residence under this program, we should also keep in mind that already the UNHCR has supervised the resettlement of some 380,000 Cambodians back into Cambodia from border camps in places such as Thailand. The advice from the UNHCR officials is that the human rights situation within Cambodia is such that those 380,000 people who have returned are in safety and that others who return would not be imperilled because of any aspect that would make them refugees.

I should also stress that not only will this program be available to those whom Senator Teague talks about and those who are already in Cambodia but that there are a number of people in camps in the region with links in Australia who may also be able to qualify once they return to Cambodia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Will the minister be tabling any statement in the parliament or making a public statement today or this week? Is this `package', as the minister refers to it, specific to Cambodia? If not, why is it not used in other countries such as those that are the source of persons who are in the humanitarian program now? Finally, I ask the question that I put originally: why is the government announcing this program at this time, given the current inquiry by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, which is examining Australia's detention practices and is due to report in December?

—The government will be making an announcement sometime later today. The details of it will be made available to everybody. In terms of the third part of the question, the government is keeping a close interest in the detention inquiry being conducted by the joint standing committee.

PARA.TAB: What we are doing here is consistent with the obligations under the current regime of detention. No-one who is in Australia will be able to apply from within Australia to access this program. As both Senator Teague and I know, those who are in Australia on detention now are people who have been refused refugee status and are now pursuing cases through judicial review. We will ensure that the detention regime operates to cover them whilst they are pursuing, exploring and exploiting the accesses available to them under the law.

This program is 6,300 strong this financial year, but the Cambodian component of it will be only 50 or so this financial year and a couple of hundred next financial year. The program does operate in other countries; for example, former Yugoslavia. It also operates and has operated for a number of years for the Timorese. So it does operate as a consistent program across the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Coulter asked me a question about the dumping of radioactive waste by Russia into the Sea of Japan. I am now able to confirm that that did occur. That has been conceded by the Russian authorities. There is a detailed response, which I have given to Senator Coulter. With his permission, and that of the Senate, I will incorporate that in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: It does appear that the Russians have dumped nuclear waste in the Sea of Japan as alleged by Greenpeace. The Russian ministry for the Protection of the Environment and Natural Resources has now confirmed that 900 cubic metres of low-level nuclear waste was dumped off the Sea of Japan on 16 October.

The waste was reported to contain strontium, cobalt and caesium with a total of 2.18 curies of radioactivity being released in 1700 cubic metres of liquid waste. According to the ministry spokesman, the dumping had been carried out in accordance with international law and regulations.
The Russians have claimed that lack of land-based storage facilities has led them to pursue ocean dumping.

Australia remains vigorously opposed to the dumping of radioactive waste at sea. In the South Pacific forum communique issued in August, Australia joined with the South Pacific island countries and New Zealand in expressing its grave concern over the dumping of Russian nuclear wastes into the North Pacific, called for its immediate cessation, and called for retrieval of those wastes if feasible and safe.

As a party to the London Convention (formal title London Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter 1972), Australia will support at the 16th consultative meeting of the London convention to be held in November this year an amendment to the convention to transform the current voluntary moratorium on the dumping at sea of low-level radioactive wastes into a compulsory regime prohibiting the dumping of all types of radioactive waste.

Senator Coulter is no doubt aware that although at present the London convention prohibits the dumping of medium and high level radioactive wastes at sea, there is only a non-legally binding moratorium in force in relation to low level radioactive waste.

Australia would expect nevertheless all parties to the London convention, including the Russian Federation to act in a manner consistent with the object and purpose of the convention and require all vessels flying their flag to comply with that moratorium.

The government knows that all enriched uranium product and depleted uranium waste from the enrichment of Australian-obligated uranium was removed under `all in all out' arrangement. Consequently I can give an unequivocal guarantee that no waste generated from Australian uranium was dumped in the sea by the Russians.

Under the 1990 agreement between Australia and the former USSR governing the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, no Australian uranium may be supplied to the successor state of the agreement; the Russian Federation for end-use in that state.

Before the signing of the agreement in 1990, the USSR carried out enrichment of Australian obligated uranium on behalf of third parties with whom Australia has nuclear safeguards agreements, such as Finland and Sweden. Under these agreements, Australian-obligated uranium could be enriched in the USSR, however all uranium had to be returned to the third party after enrichment and could not remain in the USSR for end use.

Material first entered the USSR in June 1983 and was all out by June of 1985. Under the all-in-all-out arrangement, the depleted uranium waste (tails) was also removed from the USSR as well as the enriched uranium product.

Since the completion of the agreement, there have been no transactions between Australia and the Russian Federation of Australian-obligated uranium. All Australian material which entered the former USSR has been satisfactorily accounted for and none has remained for end use within the Russian Federation.
For uranium to be supplied to Russia for end use, an entirely new agreement would need to be negotiated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is very deeply concerned by this development. Although there is no formal legal prohibition on the dumping at sea of low level waste—as distinct from high to medium level waste—there has been a non-legally binding moratorium in place. The policy aspect of that is clear and strongly adhered to by Australia.

PARA.TAB: As to the other part of Senator Coulter's question, I can give an unequivocal guarantee that no waste generated from Australian uranium could have been dumped in the sea by the Russians. All Australian material which entered the former USSR has been satisfactorily accounted for under an all-in, all-out arrangement. None has remained for end use within the Russian federation and no such material has been given subsequently. That is the response, in summary, to the latter part of Senator Coulter's question, but a much fuller answer has now been incorporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) this day, to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter on 18 October 1993, relating to Russia's dumping of radioactive waste.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the minister for the longer reply which he provided today, but I am disturbed by several matters which he raises in his answer, namely, that this waste was reported to contain: strontium, presumably strontium 90, which has a half-life of some 28 years; cobalt, presumably cobalt 60, which has a half-life of some 10 years; and caesium, presumably caesium 137, with a half-life of about 30 years. So although the materials which are being dumped are in small amounts in terms of their total quantity—and the total quantity is given as 2.18 curies—these materials will be present in the marine environment for quite a considerable length of time.

PARA.TAB: These are all materials which are taken up by biological systems and can therefore undergo very considerable bio-concentration. Strontium, particularly, is taken up into bones and therefore can be concentrated in that form. Caesium is preferentially taken up into muscles and, of course, can be concentrated there. If they were to enter food chains, the amounts of radioactivity imbibed by humans who eat fish or other material from the ocean could be quite considerable.

The minister goes on to explain that the Australian uranium which entered Russia was provided to third nations and simply underwent the increase in the concentration of the fissile uranium and that the material which went into Russia was all subsequently removed from Russia. The minister does not, however, indicate where the depleted uranium—the uranium 238, which had a smaller amount of uranium 235—went. I would be very pleased to hear where that went because we have subsequently learnt that the Americans, for instance, used depleted uranium in some of the shells used in the recent Iraqi war, and that has resulted in very considerable amounts of radioactive contamination in the areas of Iraq and Kuwait.

I would like the minister, at some subsequent time, to indicate where the depleted uranium went. Did it come back to Australia or did it go on to some third or fourth nation where it may have been used in a totally illegal and environmentally harmful way? I thank the Senate for its permission to make these few comments. I believe the matter is serious and I am pleased to know that the government will be pursuing the matter more vigorously.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

They are not in a position to delete the equal pay unit in industrial relations; they are not in a position, as government, to delete the work and family pay unit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The minister is continuing to defame the opposition. She has put this about for some years now. It is totally untrue, and I ask you to have her withdraw.

—It is not inaccurate. The opposition should correct its policy. (Time expired)

—The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) continues to go along with this garbage that the opposition is somehow planning to abolish the Office of the Status of Women. We heard this during the last election campaign. It was totally untrue then and it is totally untrue now. But it does not seem to matter what the truth is to this minister; she will spout the same amount of verbiage no matter what the truth is. She would do it under water or under concrete.

PARA.TAB: The situation also is that in estimate committees in the past Senator Crowley and her predecessor have been told exactly what the deficiencies are in the Office of the Status of Women and they have been told that it badly needed improvement. I have asked questions and pointed out publicly over a long period just what the failures are.

I know this will surprise the minister: I welcome the review, but I have two criticisms. My first criticism is that it has taken this government so long to realise that there are no outcomes of the Office of the Status of Women to review. It is timely that there be a review of the office to make sure that in future it does a good job for the women of Australia.

I point out that the Office of the Status of Women was singularly invisible when it came to doing something meaningful for the part-time women workers of Australia and the women who work in the home who have no access to meaningful retirement income. The opposition came up with some valuable policies for women in the retirement income area. But the Office of the Status of Women was totally silent on that issue. In any meaningful debate we have had in Australia in recent years the Office of the Status of Women has been invisible. There was clear evidence of this when Dr Anne Summers on the eve of the election suddenly tried to pull the government's failure on women's issues out of the fire for the Prime Minister as he was going to an election and she tried to show that the government had some sort of record for producing policy in this area.

The other thing I object to in relation to the matter we are debating now is the rudeness and lack of courtesy shown by the government to the opposition when the entire press gallery was invited to the function yesterday and the opposition was not. The minister did not even invite the spokesperson from the opposition on the status of women. We all would like to have been invited. It seems very strange that the press gallery is invited en masse but the minister cannot even invite the opposition spokesperson on the status of women.

This government has a pretty poor approach when it comes to parliamentary niceties. It is inclined to disregard the parliament when it suits it, unless it goes crawling to one or two members of the parliament when it needs a vote here and there. Otherwise the sort of—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not elegant language.

—It is perfectly true, though. When did we last have a ministerial statement in this place, for example? We have the ministers of this government going outside and making their announcements to the press gallery or at some function. This is the place where over many decades ministerial statements have been made and they are not being made in here any more. Week in and week out we have no ministerial statements. They are announced somewhere else. That is just another example of how this government has no appreciation for its position as a government that should be accountable to the parliament.

PARA.TAB: It may sound a piddling little thing talking about whether Senator Crowley invited the opposition to the announcement of a review of the Office of the Status of Women when she invited the whole of the press gallery. It is just symbolic of the failure of this government to deem itself accountable to the whole of this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Politics of exclusion.

—Politics of exclusion in almost every area. I am glad that the Office of the Status of Women is being reviewed. I hope it means that this government will, for instance, put money into the APPOINT computer system that I have asked questions about for a long time. I hope that it will mean this government will stop talking about appointing women to boards and committees and do something about it.

PARA.TAB: Over several years, I have consistently asked question after question about the promotion of women in the public sector under this government. The government has policies of talk. It does not have policies of action. The government is to be condemned for its previous failures. I welcome the fact that the government now looks as if it is trying to do something. I am worried about whether it will just be more talk or whether we will get some action this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a short explanation under standing order 191. Senator Crowley said that her office had offered to brief me, and that is correct. My office did receive two phone calls from Senator Crowley's office, one of which informed me that we could be briefed—but the briefing was offered for yesterday afternoon, when in fact the review was released at 10 a.m. That is not good enough. I put on the public record that Senator Crowley was correct in saying that she offered to have one of her staff brief us, but in the afternoon, well after the event, well after Senator Crowley had issued her press releases and well after the women who were involved had gone away. I do not think that was good enough.

—I rise in this debate because I think it is important to note that we have undertaken a very important review of the Office of the Status of Women. However, the comments of members of the opposition that this office has made no contribution to women's issues are totally spurious.
—We have never said that.

—Senator Newman said that the office had made no contribution. Let us talk about the domestic violence program. Who has been at the forefront of work done in this country on the prevention of domestic violence and the changing of community attitudes so that domestic violence is unacceptable? It has to be said that the Office of the Status of Women and the National Women's Consultative Council have played an important role in this very important issue. They have provided the support, provided the information and done a lot of the very hard work that has gone into this.

PARA.TAB: The office has also led the way in issues such as child care and the needs of women with children. It has also played an important role in the accreditation area. It has wanted to make sure, as has the government, that child care in this country is of a standard that is suitable for all children, is of high quality and is accessible. These are the sorts of things that this office has been involved with, and for those reasons it is very important.

We also have seen the Office of the Status of Women involved in the reviews that have been undertaken on the portrayal of women in the media. People would be very much aware that the portrayal of women in the media has been appalling, particularly in relation to sport. Women's sport has not been receiving the coverage that is needed and the office has been very much involved in this area.

It has also undertaken, in very recent times, the review of the National Agenda for Women, a statement launched five years ago as part of our commitment to United Nations international women's programs. We have now reviewed that document and, earlier this year, a revised National Agenda for Women was published and launched. That has been a very important document because it has enabled us to review the programs that are available, accessible and suitable for women within all of the government departments. Not only have we been able to review them; we have also been able to comment on the implementation, what needs to be done and where we need to go to next. These are the sorts of things that this office has been involved with, and they are very important. These are the sorts of things that this government supports and is working very hard towards.

The office has also supported very strongly the breast cancer screening program. We know what importance this has to the women of Australia. This is of the utmost importance for those women who should be participating in the scheme. It is able to provide information to women on the groups that should be utilising mammography screening. This office understands the difference between mammography screening and diagnostic mammography. Many women's organisations and many women that I meet—including some members of the opposition on previous occasions—do not understand the difference between mammography screening and mammographic diagnostic procedures. It is very important that we make sure that this is known.

The office is ensuring that the age group of the women who enter into this screening process is widely known. It is women of 50-plus years of age who should be screened. The program will not be turning away women who are over 40, but it is important that this campaign be directed to women of the appropriate age, that is, 50-plus, post-menopausal women. It is appropriate that women realise that mammographic screening will not stop breast cancer. If they have a mammography every two years, it does not mean that they do not have to continue with breast self-examination.

These sorts of things are of vital importance to the breast cancer screening program. It has been the Office of the Status of Women which has been able to bring to the government its knowledge of women's health needs in this country. For that, we should recognise the contribution of this office. We recognise there have been shortcomings in this report. That will be addressed. But I think it is very important that we do not just stand back and say, `Nothing of any worth or value has come out of this office'. It has made a significant contribution to the women of this country. For that, the women of this country are very supportive and grateful.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to questions without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate (Senator Boswell) and Senators Alston, Parer and Panizza this day, relating to native title.

SPEECH.PARA: There were six questions asked today by the opposition in relation to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote them?
—A series of people, all very high-powered.
—Who wrote them? Why don't you admit it for once?
—Various people write them. I do not see why that is terribly relevant.
—You didn't, did you? They were too incompetent for you to have written them.

—I see. This is an indication of the sort of passion that is generated to the point where Senator Robert Ray needs to ask who wrote a question. The important thing is what questions were asked and what answers were given. I think we have a very real problem. Those questions were deliberately designed to elicit information in order to find out the basis on which these grandiose proposals were announced yesterday and to try to ascertain some fairly sensible answers to questions which are disturbing vast numbers of people around the countryside.

PARA.TAB: In that sort of spirit, if this government is serious about Mabo as an issue—instead of engaging in some sort of cheap point scoring exercise, as Senator Robert Ray thinks it ought to be—I would have thought it would be very concerned to spell out, for example, the proportion of landmass which could be subject to native title claims; what analysis has been done; the extent to which there might be compensation payable; what rights attach to native title; what the cost sharing arrangements will be; and the effect on crown land of native title claims.

The answer given by Senator Gareth Evans on that last point was very enlightening. He said that it will be decided on a case by case basis, meaning that it will be some years before many of these claims are finally determined by the courts. In the meantime, there will be all manner of claims. Whether they are serious or otherwise will not really matter to those who are subject to these claims because they will have that sword of Damocles hanging over their heads. They will be particularly anxious to try to bring certainty back into the exercise, particularly if they are conducting very substantial pastoral properties or mining activities. Therefore, they will effectively be compelled to negotiate settlements.

That, of course, has nothing to do with the merits of the claims; that simply has to do with the fact that a claim has been brought. That is a very serious matter of concern, particularly to the many thousands of people who are likely to be affected. Yet all we got was a torrent of abuse from Senator Gareth Evans. I think we were called scavengers today; we were called all sorts of unmentionables yesterday. The riffraff opposite were constantly interjecting and trying to belittle the questions as though they were not serious and therefore not deserving of answers.

The best that Senator Ray could do was to ask who wrote these questions. We do not bother asking those opposite who wrote their dorothy dixers. These questions cover a wide range of issues which are of great concern to the population. If Senator Robert Ray does not want to face up to that, if he wants to somehow pretend that the grammar was not to his liking, or if he would like to have had other subject matters canvassed—

TALK.START.PARA: —The content.

—The content was perfectly clear, as it was made obvious by the fulminations of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. He was at pains to avoid providing any substantive answers to very simple questions—such as what proportion of land is affected and what compensation is likely to be paid. I did not think there was any particular deficiency in the form of the questions. I thought there were manifest deficiencies in the form of the answers because they were deliberate exercises in refusing to answer questions and therefore simply adding fuel to the fire.

PARA.TAB: Members of the government should not go around this countryside blaming us for whipping up scaremongering when the fact of the matter is that the government is deliberately choosing not to provide answers which it clearly ought to know. One assumes, despite all the triple backflips with pike that we have seen in recent times, that somewhere someone has been doing a bit of research and has come up with some basic information and statistics, but for the government's own reasons it is not prepared to release that sort of information to the public. It cannot really blame us or anyone else for being concerned about where these policies are likely to take Australia.

I think it is a matter of profound regret that the government seems to have embarked on a course and has no idea how it will end. It has no idea what it is likely to cost. It has no idea who is likely to be affected. It has no idea how long it might take for claims to be resolved. In other words, the end result will be massive uncertainty brought about quite purposefully on the government's part presumably for some political advantage. If the government were fair dinkum about this exercise it would be swamping us with facts and figures to demonstrate that these claims are very containable. Instead, all we get are throwaway lines such as, `The cost will be very small' and `There will be a minuscule number of claims'. If that is the best the government can do, it deserves to have the Australian community very concerned indeed. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
