SPEECH.PARA: The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill 1993 forms part of a package of seven cognate bills which are being introduced today. Taken together, these Bills will substantially increase the level of prudential protection provided to the superannuation industry, and represent a substantial strengthening of the security of superannuation savings and of the protection of the rights of superannuation fund members.

The Bills give effect to the new prudential arrangements for superannuation that were announced on behalf of the Government on 21 October 1992 in the Treasurer's statement Strengthening Super Security.

The Government is introducing this legislation in order to give added protection to superannuation savings and to promote a more efficient superannuation industry, while avoiding the imposition of unreasonable supervisory and compliance costs. The long-term benefits of these carefully balanced measures will significantly outweigh the costs of their implementation.
The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill 1993 now before the Senate provides:

for effective supervisory arrangements involving direct enforcement powers for the Insurance and Superannuation Commission enabling effective enforcement of the prudential requirements and obligations placed on funds and trustees;

for trustees and investment managers to be made subject to adequate legislative sanctions for the proper performance of their fiduciary responsibilities and increasing their accountability to their members;
clear delineation of the basic duties and responsibilities of trustees, and indicating that trustees have primary responsibility for the operation of funds;
that trustees and investment managers must be suitable to act as fund trustees and to manage fund moneys respectively;
for financial assistance to be provided to funds that have suffered a loss owing to fraudulent conduct or theft;
mechanisms for dealing with benefits in employer-sponsored funds in respect of members that have left employment or who are lost, and of unclaimed benefits;

SPEECH.PARA: The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill makes various amendments to:
modify a provision which has been used to cover productivity superannuation determinations, to reflect the fact that they are no longer "interim";
modify the right of appeal from Conscientious Objection Tribunals to reflect more accurately the role of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal;
streamline procedures covering command and discipline where forces of Australia and other countries are serving together;
enable trustees of four welfare funds to be appointed by a Minister rather than by the Governor-General;
remove an unintended double benefit for a small number of members of the Defence Force who have transferred to the new Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme; and
provide a special home loans benefit for members of the Defence Force allotted for warlike service.
Before dealing in more detail with the last two matters, which are of greater significance, I would like to make a few observations on the other amendments.
The superannuation determination amendments are simply to ensure that there is proper authority for determinations dealing with ongoing superannuation benefits for members of the Defence Force.

The conscientious objection amendments would modify a right of appeal. Where a Conscientious Objection Tribunal has determined an application, there is a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal ("AAT") then to the Federal Court. At present, the Federal Court could hear a conscientious objection appeal from the AAT on a question of law and, with the leave of the Court, on any other ground. The amendments would eliminate the right of appeal on grounds other than questions of law, to accord with current administrative law policy whereby the AAT provides final merits review.

I should add that, although these amendments are necessary to reflect administrative law policy, they are not expected to have any practical effect. This is because questions of conscientious objection arise only in the context of conscription, and there could be no conscription unless Australia was under direct threat of attack.

The amendments to streamline command and discipline procedures where forces of Australia and other countries serve together will avoid the requirement for a series of formal declarations where ongoing cooperation could be anticipated. A standing declaration, to cover a particular country, would invoke mutual powers of command and discipline whenever the forces of that country were serving together with ours. Of course, this facility would only be used for close allies where we could anticipate ongoing international cooperation, for example, in peacekeeping activities.

The amendments to enable a Minister instead of the Governor-General to appoint trustees of welfare trust funds are part of an ongoing process of relieving the Governor-General from involvement in the detail of Defence Force administration. The trusts in question administer welfare funds for each Service of the Defence Force and retirement units for ex-Air Force personnel.
I now turn to the two more significant matters in the bill.

The amendments to remove a double benefit for a small number of members of the Defence Force who have transferred to the new Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme will correct a drafting omission. The error would allow some members who elected to transfer from the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme to receive a double benefit.

The amendments have retrospective effect to the commencement of the new Scheme on 1 October 1991, to remove the liability for the double benefit for members who have retired since then. Recent changes to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Rules have removed the problem for affected members who retire after 21 April 1993.

There are two groups of members eligible to receive double benefits: Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme members who had retired with a pension; and members who had separated from the Defence Force and transferred their benefits to another superannuation scheme.

Where a member of either group re-entered the Defence Force and then transferred to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme, the drafting error would allow the member to retain the benefit derived from contributions paid in the first period of service and also to be paid those contributions again with interest. The amendments would remove the entitlement to the unintended double benefit.

43 former members are affected. They have been advised in writing that any payment of the double benefit would be recoverable but, as no additional monies have been paid to date, it is hoped to avoid the need for recovery action.
On a more positive note, I come to the amendments to provide a special home loans benefit for members of the Defence Force who have been allotted for warlike service.

In May of this year the Government agreed to a framework for conditions of service where members of the Defence Force are deployed overseas. The Government's aim is to ensure that members who are deployed overseas will be assured of consistent and timely benefits.

An important element of the agreed conditions is an enhanced home loans benefit for personnel allotted to service declared as "warlike". This benefit will apply to members involved in the recent operational service in Cambodia, Somalia and the former Yugoslavia. The same benefit will be available for members allotted for service in any future overseas operation of a comparable nature.

The additional benefit comprises waiver of the requirement for a qualifying period of 6 years service together with an additional subsidy period ranging from 2 to 5 years, depending on the length of warlike service. For example, members who have completed operational service in Somalia will now qualify for waiver of the 6 year qualifying period and an additional subsidy period of 3 years. The maximum subsidy period is also increased from 20 to 25 years.

As I have indicated, these benefits will be available also to all personnel allotted for future service declared as warlike and represent an ongoing commitment by the Government to see overseas service by Defence Force personnel appropriately recognised.

The kinds of operation in question are an essential element of Australia's determination to play a fitting role as a good international citizen. As the burden of that role often falls on members of the Defence Force who are deployed in extremely difficult circumstances, I am sure the Senate will support the Government's measures to establish a suitable framework for the associated conditions of service.
I commend the bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure relates to the proposal by the government in this budget to extend the fringe benefits tax to business travel. The evidence presented to the committee, which is contained in the report, clearly shows this to be a flawed proposal both in revenue terms and in equity terms.

PARA.TAB: As the report indicates, it has been very difficult for the committee to meet the terms of reference given to it by the Senate because of the indeterminate nature of this proposal, in particular, the rate which is to be struck to be regarded as a reasonable level beyond which fringe benefits tax is to apply to business travel accommodation. With that rate not having been provided to the committee, indeed, not having yet been formulated by the government, it was impossible for any accurate assessment to be made by the committee of the impact of this proposal on the tourism industry, the accommodation industry and related industries.

Of course, as a consequence of that the government has now withdrawn this particular part of the bill and, it is reported, will reintroduce it at a later stage. In terms of revenue, I simply say that all the evidence given before the committee indicated that, if this legislation were to be introduced, it would not raise revenue because business would ensure that whatever provisions were made for the accommodation of its employees were below the threshold. Therefore, fringe benefits tax would not result and the government would derive no revenue.

The other argument that has been put in favour of this proposal is that of equity—that it is an equity measure to ensure that what the government regards as unacceptably lavish standards of accommodation are not provided to business employees. In response to questions I asked of all witnesses before the committee—those from the accommodation and tourism sector, or the business sector generally, as well as the government representatives, the officials of Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office—they could not provide any evidence at all that businesses, in arrangement with their employees, provide a higher or more lavish standard of accommodation when those employees are required to travel on business activities in return for a lower salary. In other words, no evidence could be put forward to the committee that employees are substituting lavish accommodation arrangements for salary and thereby avoiding legitimate income tax on their salary. That is the first point to be made with regard to the equity argument—that there is no evidence of inequity in the current arrangements because no evidence could be provided that tax is being avoided through this process.

The second argument in favour of equity put to the committee by the government representatives related to personal benefit—that, in their view, some personal benefit was derived by business employees when they travelled by staying in accommodation of standards above a prescribed level. I asked those representatives how that level of personal benefit could be measured, particularly in comparison with the situation of an employee who was not required to travel and was therefore able to remain in the comfort and familiar surroundings of his or her home. I asked how it was possible to assess the measure of personal benefit between one being accommodated at a certain level of accommodation when being required to travel away from home on business and being able to stay in one's own home. The response was that this was a subjective judgment. In other words, there is no objective basis on which this so-called personal benefit, which the government alleges is derived by certain business employees when required to travel, can be assessed. Therefore, on both aspects of the equity argument raised by the government, there is no case for this proposal.

The minority report, which was prepared by my colleagues Senators Gibson and Macdonald along with me, highlights this as one of the obvious shortcomings in the government's arguments for this legislation. We also include in that minority report a number of other reservations that we have about this proposal which have arisen as a direct result of the evidence presented to the committee hearings. Therefore, we certainly welcome the fact that the government has now withdrawn this particular proposal from the tax bill within which it was included. That tax bill will proceed with other measures, but with this particular proposal to extend the fringe benefits tax withdrawn from it. It was suggested to us that this bill will return as a separate bill in the future when the government has undertaken further consultation with the industry and also has provided a discussion paper for the industry and, indeed, for us as members of the committee to consider.

I might suggest to the government that it let this particular proposal disappear without trace. If it does reappear as a separate piece of legislation, that legislation should be subjected to the very closest scrutiny, as we have recommended in our minority report, to determine its impact on the industry and, of course, its equity circumstances. As I have said, in the evidence provided to this committee thus far, there is no justification for this proposal either on equity or on revenue grounds. That is why we have put forward this minority report which, while accepting the recommendations and conclusions reached by the majority of the committee, adds to it our particular concerns and our severe reservations about, and indeed opposition to, this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address briefly the government's provisions to impose threshold levels on excess travel costs which were, until the government's decision to withdraw them, part of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993.

PARA.TAB: The government's effort is rather a sad and sorry saga. While the objective—to ensure that the potential for any rorts in this area was excluded—was generally agreed, the government was not able to provide sufficient information to the committee or at any other stage to show that it had given adequate consideration to the effect of the proposed provisions on investment and employment in the accommodation and hospitality industries; nor, indeed, was it able to show that the objective would actually be achieved, or the extent to which it could be achieved, if such rorts in fact existed.

While it is clear that the government had some anecdotal evidence and, clearly, there is an issue of equity involved in terms of the taxpayer subsidising benefits which may be granted to an employee by the employer—or, in the case of a self-employed person, in terms of expending what one could term `excessive amounts' on travel—the government has not been able to substantiate these arguments. To me, how the government proposes to address the reduction in investment and employment in the industry remains a very important question.

We have had some evidence that when the tax deductibility of business lunches—as it was colloquially known—was withdrawn, turnover in the restaurant industry, which was catering for that trade, fell by 50 per cent; it recovered later to show a continuing reduction of 20 per cent. But here we have had no such assessments or no such figures.

I think there is an additional difficulty in this particular proposal and the way the government went about it. The Senate was asked to approve the enabling legislation, leaving the actual threshold levels to be determined later by regulation. Clearly, that would have left the Senate in the position where disallowing the regulations was the only remedy, with a resulting uncertainty in the industry. But, to top it, the government expected the Senate to proceed to make that decision to pass the enabling legislation without providing the discussion paper which it is compiling on the basis of its consultations with the industry to determine what in fact would be a reasonable threshold level. I believe that such procedure is really quite unheard of. Obviously, the Democrats welcome the government decision, which we asked for, to withdraw these provisions relating to FBT on excess travel from the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 and to reintroduce them in a separate bill.

In my dissenting report, I make the point that I am calling on the government to include the threshold levels which it wishes to introduce as part of that legislation and not expect the Senate to give it carte blanche to introduce them by regulation later. However, it is to be expected that, no matter where the threshold levels are placed, some reduction in turnover for the Australian tourism, travel and hospitality industries will result.

Therefore the second recommendation in my dissenting report is that the government include a provision in that legislation to remove tax deductibility for conventions held abroad by Australian companies. It is ludicrous that it is now possible for a professional or commercial organisation which is composed solely of Australian members to hold a convention or conference in Bali or Fiji, to spend Australian dollars in those places, supporting that nation's tourism and hospitality industries, and then to come back to Australia and ask for a tax deduction for the amounts expended.

It seems to me that in this situation our industries need not only certainty—and we have asked for that in the legislation that is to be introduced; legislation which we will be able to scrutinise and, if necessary, amend—but also some tangible support. I believe that by removing the tax deductibility in this circumstance we would be providing that tangible support and encouraging Australian organisations to hold their conventions within Australia rather than take them to other countries in the region.

The Australian Democrats do not resile from the need to find some appropriate measures to ensure that the potential for travel rorts of the kind that were claimed to be taking place is excluded. We will insist that these measures not harm our industries and we will expect them to be effective in achieving that objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure concerns one of the pieces of budget legislation which, like much else in the budget, was ill-conceived and originated for all the wrong reasons. I think former Labor minister John Brown was correct when he said that this legislation was driven by the ideology of the Left, that the Labor Party had reverted to class envy of the worst kind for which it used to be known and which in more recent years, as a result of maturity, it had overthrown.

PARA.TAB: It seems that this legislation, the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, came about because the government was embarrassed by having slugged the poor, so to speak, with fuel tax and sales tax. It was a sop to the left wing element of the Labor Party, to the unions and to the social welfare groups. It appears—and John Brown gives credence to this—that the government said, `Oh, yes, but we're gonna get the rich businessmen too'. This piece of legislation was brought in on that basis.

It became fairly clear during the inquiry that the government had neither considered fully all aspects of this legislation nor done any work on what the legislation might impose. I suppose the thought of getting at the rich businessmen appeals to most Australians. It became obvious that this legislation did not do that. But it would cost jobs. It was estimated that between 10,000 and 20,000 young Australians would be thrown out of work as a result of this piece of ill-conceived legislation. It was also shown that, far from being a budget measure that raised $60 million, as the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) adverted to in his budget speech, it would end up costing the federal government something of that order, if not more.

The costs to industry of compliance would have been quite horrendous. Investment in the hotel and tourism industries, which we desperately need now, would have been stifled. There would have been difficulties in respect of investment in these industries, particularly at a time when Australia needs to expand in these areas. The hotel and tourism industries are two of the small number of remaining Australian industries that have anything going for them. They are two of the small number of industries in Australia that have been able to overcome the recession planned by the Labor Party. The tourism industry and the hotel and accommodation convention industry have been able to get ahead largely on the backs of overseas tourists and conventioneers who come to our country.

This legislation, which was introduced without any thought by the government, is simply a sop to the left of the Labor Party. The industry became concerned immediately after it had worked through what the effects of the legislation would be. As a result, it raised this issue. The Liberal and National parties were concerned about the issue because we felt that sufficient thought had not gone into it.

Naturally, on budget night we assumed that the government had looked seriously at and done some work on this legislation. That is what we expected, quite reasonably, on budget night. As it became very clear very quickly that that was not the case, the Liberal and National parties sought to refer this matter to a Senate committee. That is what happened, and the result is the report we are discussing today.

I give credit to the committee, particularly its chairman, Senator Childs, who conducted the inquiry very fairly. I think the committee came to a very sensible decision in its report. As Senator Spindler has said, it became clear to all of us on the committee that we were being asked to report on certain aspects of the bill when the government really did not have any detail on which we could work. It was indicated on budget night that the allowance would be somehow related to the Public Service allowance, and so the industry used that as the benchmark for some calculations. Just as we started on this inquiry, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) said, `Oh, well, I'm taking that back. We're not going to use that anymore'. So we did not quite know where we were or what was to be proposed.

What the Senate was being asked to do was pass legislation that had no detail at all—the government would come along in two or three months time and introduce some regulations that had not been initially before this chamber; regulations which could impose taxes on the tourism and hospitality industries. Initially, the Liberal members of that committee certainly could not answer questions that were asked simply because the government did not have any details. The government had not done any work on the legislation and did not know what it was all about.

It became clear from the evidence that the measure was certainly not a revenue measure. When Senator McMullan appeared before the committee, he tried to pretend or kid us that the legislation had revenue considerations and that there was big money involved. We got the old Labor Party line of `You're being irresponsible; you're holding up the budget; you're not going to give us all this money we need to pay for tax cuts'. That was the standard Senator McMullan line. But what he was saying in the committee hearing had been previously contradicted by the Assistant Treasurer who, in a letter, said, `This measure is not driven by revenue considerations'. By the end of the day, I do not think anybody believed there was any revenue in it.

We heard different evidence which could reasonably have led the committee to resolve—some members may not have come to this conclusion, but the evidence was certainly before us—that a large number of jobs would have been lost in Australia. In the end, no-one even pretended that there were any revenue considerations in the legislation. The compliance costs could have been quite substantial. I think there was a fairly clear indication that investment in the hotel industry—much-needed investment, particularly in the run-up to the Olympic Games—would have been dealt quite a severe blow.

It also became quite obvious to the committee that there had been no consultation between the government and the industry about how these quite horrific or quite substantial measures may have affected the industry. It also seemed from evidence—although Senator McMullan wiggled around the answer—that even the tourism minister was not drawn into the Treasurer's confidence when these measures were being considered.

The Liberal members on the committee were concerned about any excesses that there might be in business travel. Nobody could give us any examples of it. People used to say, `Yes, it is there'. No-one from the industry, no-one from Treasury and no-one from the Taxation Office could give us any evidence about it. One of the witnesses to the inquiry listed a series of five possible rorts and suggested that there were other ways of overcoming those rorts. Curiously, when the Taxation Office responded to that submission, it said, `You do not need new legislation to get at those rorts because we already have legislation under the existing tax acts to attack those sorts of rorts'. If we do not need new legislation, if we have it currently, why do we need this legislation to try to overcome those rorts?

I and my coalition colleagues on the committee agree with Senator Spindler that, if in the future any legislation is to come before the parliament regarding this sort of thing, it should be detailed legislation. The government should not bring it in here and say to the Senate, `You approve this in broad principle. We will not tell you what it is about. We will not give you the opportunity to investigate whether it will cost jobs, whether it will raise revenue, or whether it will cost a lot to comply with. You just approve it in principle. We will go away and do the regulations, work out the formulas and we will introduce them behind the closed door by regulation'. That is not good enough. We on this side agree with Senator Spindler—or he probably agrees with us, and it is part of the minority report that we have put in—that any further proposals should be contained entirely in the legislation and not be left to be implemented by regulation.

In our dissenting report—although it is better to say the additional conclusions in the general report, because we do agree with the majority conclusions of the report—we thought it appropriate to make two additional recommendations, one of which I have just mentioned. The other one indicated that, from what we gathered from all the evidence given to us, no case had been made out for this legislation at all. We were very doubtful that there was a need for this type of legislation. So we have additionally recommended to the Senate that if legislation regarding the so-called excess business travel expenditures is again brought before the Senate, it should be subjected by this Senate to the most intense scrutiny to establish: firstly, the need; secondly, the purpose; and, thirdly, the effect of that legislation. Whilst it has been put in other words, all members of the committee—Labor members, Democrat members and certainly the Liberal members—agree that if this legislation were to come before us again, it should be subjected to the most intense scrutiny by this chamber.

Although we in the Liberal and National parties have not had any time to seriously consider the second recommendation proposed by Senator Spindler, it would seem at first glance that it is not something that we could support. It is building up the tariff walls again, saying that any Australian conventioneers who go overseas will be penalised in a tax way if that happens. I think Senator Burns quite rightly pointed out that, if we start doing that, we will certainly get into a trade war with our trading partners and it would not be very long before all the Americans and Japanese and Asians who came to Australia for conventions would be subjected to tax penalties in their own countries for coming here. I really do not want to get involved in that; I suggest to Senator Spindler that he would have a lot of convincing to do if he wanted us to agree with that.

As this matter has been left, the Assistant Treasurer—who seems to be in charge of all of this—is indicating that he will talk further with the industry. The Assistant Treasurer somewhat belatedly—nevertheless it is welcome—instituted some sort of dialogue with the industry and has called for and received submissions. It is the Assistant Treasurer's intention, as I understand it, to publish a discussion paper which he will then make available to members of the committee and to the Senate so the matter can be further considered. I certainly hope that the Assistant Treasurer will come to the conclusion rapidly, if he has not done so already several weeks ago. I suspect that is what it is all about; I think he realised a couple of weeks ago that this was all wrong and that what he needed to do was to try to extricate himself and the government as best and as quickly as he could. If he has not come to that conclusion, I am quite sure that, by the end of this consultation period, he will have come to that conclusion.

I certainly hope that the government would think very seriously and very long about whether there is really any necessity to do this. If there are a couple of perceived rorts, then I think we have been told quite clearly that there are other ways of attacking it. It does not raise revenue. It could affect jobs. So why bother with it? I just hope this is another one of those pieces of legislation in this 1993 budget that will be thrown onto the ever growing discard pile. I think in this instance that is appropriate.

I magnanimously say to the Assistant Treasurer and to the government that they do deserve at least some congratulation for realising when things need to be done away with; when they have got out of their depth they have been prepared to pull out. I hope they maintain that mature approach and that this is the last we see of this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue debate on the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 which concern the proposed increase in levy on fuels. As I said last night, I am very concerned about what this measure and other measures in the budget are doing to the investment climate here in Australia. Why is this important? It is only through investment that we are going to grow jobs in this economy. Unless we have an attractive investment climate, unemployment will not go down, and that is what we need to fix.

PARA.TAB: Last night I made mention of the fact that virtually all the OECD countries are doing three things: they are containing their budget deficits; they are increasing savings; and they are deregulating their labour markets. What are we doing? We are heading in the reverse direction. With regard to the labour market, it is obvious that the government has given in to the ACTU on genuine enterprise agreements concerning non-union labour. It is now threatening to give in with regard to secondary boycotts, which is going in the reverse direction to that of the rest of the world. Those measures are sure to guarantee double digit unemployment in this country for quite a long time.

In the June quarter of this year national savings fell by 1.2 per cent of GDP—about $1.2 billion. This was the largest single quarterly fall since 1974. National savings fell by $3.2 billion last financial year. The main culprit is the federal government. As the FitzGerald report aptly pointed out, the government's deficits are the main problem with regard to savings in Australia. Here we have a government saying that its budget is about jobs but its policies are heading in the reverse direction.

Investment in Australia is in crisis. Investment in plant and equipment in Australia for the last two financial years has been less than six per cent of GDP—the lowest level since World War II. The level should be around eight to 10 per cent. That needs encouragement. We should compare this with our competitive country just across the Tasman—New Zealand—where unemployment is now below 10 per cent, capital expenditure is expanding quite substantially and the budget deficit and the current account deficit are close to balance. It is not hard to see that the New Zealand dollar will be equivalent to the Australian dollar in the not too distant future.

What should we be doing? We should be lowering costs and increasing savings. We need to free up the labour market and lower costs in the transport industry. What are we doing in the transport industry? The increase in levies proposed in these two bills will increase transport costs substantially. The fuel levy will increase shipping costs. I will not go into the details, which my colleagues went over yesterday, but we are well aware that shipping costs will go up substantially. The estimates are that shipping costs around the coast will increase by 2.1 per cent—$360,000 per ship. It is a very important matter to my home state of Tasmania. It means that all goods in Tasmania will go up in price.

Other transport costs for road and rail will also go up very substantially. The industry estimates that this fuel levy will increase road costs by three per cent across the nation. With our road and rail transport costs being so important in our huge nation, the cost of everything will go up. In addition, we will have an increased levy on fuel oil. Last night my colleague Senator Parer mentioned two mines in detail—Savage River, in my home state of Tasmania, and the Nabalco alumina refinery at Gove in northern Australia. Without going into the details, the problems at Savage River are serious. The excise will increase the cost of product by $1.15 per tonne when the value of the product is $36.60 per tonne. That will be a quite substantial increase in the cost of the product. Management has no doubt that this matter could easily cause the early closure of the mine. The feasibility study for taking the mine underground is certainly at risk.

In northern Australia we have the extraordinary example of the Nabalco alumina refinery. In one fell swoop, its costs are expected to rise by $25 million per year. We might think that Nabalco does not matter as it is just a foreign owned enterprise. That is not true. Whilst 70 per cent of it is owned by Swiss Aluminium Australia Ltd and basically managed by that company, CSR owns about 20 per cent and the AMP Society, superannuation funds and similar groups own a further 10 per cent. It is one of 32 alumina refineries in the world, but unfortunately its energy costs are the fourth highest in the world. Here we have a government, without even conferring with it, putting a $25 million cost impost on that enterprise. Those are some excellent examples of the government, without really thinking about what it was doing, imposing substantial costs on business and providing a further deterrent to investment in Australia.

How do we increase savings? As the FitzGerald report pointed out quite clearly, the federal government is the main culprit for decreasing savings. We applaud the government's aim to chase a one per cent deficit by 1995-96 but it ought to be chasing a surplus by then because that is what is really required to return Australia to a position where it is making savings. We cannot go on accumulating debt. We have to increase savings in Australia.

The government is not taking this matter seriously enough. The investment climate here is extremely bad. Not many Australians really understand that investment is now a global business. Investment does not have to take place here in Australia. Neither Australian savings nor foreigners' savings have to be invested here. One interesting statistic I came across a while ago showed that over 50 per cent of Australian money put into trust funds of various sorts during the last quarter—the quarter ended 30 June—went off-shore. The AMP Society—the largest investor in Australia—is saying publicly that its policy is to put 25 per cent of its funds off-shore. Why? Because it does not have the confidence to invest here in Australia.

Investors have to be persuaded—we are not talking about just big projects but small projects as well—that it is worth while to invest here in Australia. Until that happens, there will be no decrease in unemployment and no optimistic future for our children. Instead of imposing this additional cost on fuel, the government must cut its costs. We are expected to approve a levy on fuel which puts up all business costs across the nation when the government puts up its own expenditure by 3.9 per cent in real terms this year, on top of increases of 5.3 per cent and 5.5 per cent for the last two years. So we have seen a 15 per cent increase in real costs for the Commonwealth government over the last three years.

In the real world, any managing director who could not cut costs by 10 per cent would be sacked. That is what has been going on right across the board if we take note of what has been happening in the private sector in Australia. Firms have been achieving that and much higher rates of cost reduction in order to survive against the harsh competitive world. Yet the Commonwealth government seems to be insulated from all of this. Even state governments are meeting those targets and reducing their costs substantially. So why is the government imposing taxes when we really should be tackling cost reduction within the Commonwealth government? That is the issue, and I support the Opposition's case against these bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak against the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. In doing so, I am reminded of the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on budget night some two months ago which he started off by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians. Too many are now out of work. Too many have been out of work for too long.

There are a lot of ordinary Australians who wish he had stopped his budget speech right then because they were the only real facts in the whole of those 14 pages. From then on there was far less of an element of truth in what he said. In the very next sentence he said:
The primary objective of this budget is jobs.

I fail to see how a budget can have a primary objective of jobs when one of the most cruel measures in that budget is to increase costs by way of a fuel tax to all those ordinary Australians who are forced, by one means or another, to consume fuel in their daily living or business.

PARA.TAB: A fuel excise is a hidden consumption tax. The Treasurer made great play on the night of the budget of saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The government will meet its announced objectives without the introduction of a massive new indirect tax.
The only truth in that statement is that it is not a new tax. He has made sure that we have a massive indirect tax that impacts unfairly on people in Australia. He said:
The government will maintain indirect tax exemptions for the necessities of life as traditionally recognised in the Australian tax system.
Further on, when talking about the government measures, he said:
Excise on petroleum products will rise—
The budget—

recognises the harmful effect of lead in petrol, particularly on the children of Australia, and will accelerate the conversion of the motor vehicle fleet to unleaded petrol. Even if all these increases in fuel excise were implemented overnight, Australia would still have the third lowest petrol prices in the industrialised world—and among the lowest fuel taxes.

We have heard over and over again from the government, particularly from those who answer questions about the rise in fuel taxes, that we have the third lowest petrol price in the industrialised world and one of the lowest fuel taxes.But at no time have members on the government side indicated that we also happen to live in a country that has some of the vastest distances that it is possible to cover in pursuit of a living or by way of transporting goods and services to the people throughout Australia. A fuel tax, and the imposition of an increase in it, is an increased tax on every single good and service. Every good and service will be affected to a greater or lesser extent by the increase in the fuel tax. Because of our heavy reliance on road and rail transportation, the cost of the extra tax on fuel will be added to everything we buy.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that the fuel excise impacts disproportionately on people who live outside metropolitan areas. I recently conducted a survey amongst South Australian Farmers' Federation branch presidents and secretaries. I asked them to rate their level of concern in some 24 different categories of government policy which are influencing them. Honourable senators would not believe it, but what came out on top as the major concern to people who live outside the metropolitan area and to these secretaries was fuel tax—and that was prior to the introduction of the budget.

As well as fuel tax, there were concerns about commodity prices, the wool crisis, European Community and United States subsidies, stamp duty and the cost of tertiary education, but it is a fact that the major area of concern to them was the effects of a fuel tax and, certainly by now, the increase in the fuel tax. Of over 80 per cent of the farmers' federation presidents and secretaries, the major concern from all those 24 categories is the cost of fuel and the impact of the tax.

Not surprisingly, 100 per cent of those surveyed from the very northern areas of the state, and 97 per cent from the Eyre Peninsula, rated a fuel tax as their highest priority. That is not hard to understand when one considers the vast distances that these people have to transport themselves, their goods and anything that needs to be supplied to run their businesses.

This government pretends to be interested in, and concerned about, the welfare of low income people. We hear it time and time again. I have heard Senator McMullan say how concerned the government is for people on low incomes and how the policy directions that this government is going to take are directed to help those on lower incomes.

The strange part about it is that certainly most, if not all, of the low income areas in Australia which have been identified by the Industries Commission are outside the metropolitan cities in Australia. Three of them happen to be in my home state. The area of the lowest per capita income—less than $14,000 per year—is the Yorke Peninsula and the Lower North. The second lowest income in Australia is the Murray Lands, where, on average, the per capita income is still under $14,000 per year. The fourth lowest income area in Australia is on the Eyre Peninsula, where the per capita income is still below $14,000 per year.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I am quite sure that you understand this as well as anybody in the government because I know that, in company with you, we visited parts of the Eyre Peninsula last week to see some of the devastation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we did.

—We did. My colleague Senator Panizza was there and I am sure he will back me up. If Senator Murphy were there, he would have seen, throughout our committee hearings, the devastation that has occurred in that area because of natural disaster. Natural disaster is one thing that has contributed to the downfall, but these people live so far away from their source of supply for goods and services that the fuel tax increase will have a further devastating effect on them as they try to recover some form of viability into their businesses while recovering from the devastating rain damage that they suffered at the last harvest and the mouse plague that has devastated that area in the last three or four months.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, you have seen these areas, and I know you will understand the concerns that have been expressed to me, the coalition and the government on the effects of these fuel increases. I will read a few of the comments of people involved in this survey. A farmer from the south-east of South Australia said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot believe that, in a time of rural crisis, a government would be prepared to slug this section of the electorate so unfairly and not expect a severe backlash. In particular, I refer to the unjust increase in the cost of fuel and the proposed increase in Wool Tax. I will not be able to purchase any vehicles to run on unleaded fuel.
A farmer from the Eyre Peninsula who runs a mixed farm said:

Distance to get to regional centres for basic necessities and services means we use a lot of fuel, and present economic circumstances dictate that we cannot afford used [or] new vehicles, using unleaded petrol . . .
A respondent from the lower north said:

. . . daily costs of transporting our children to school are always increasing; fuel, tyres, wear and tear, deterioration of roads etc. Now with [the] proposed increase in fuel tax we are blatantly discriminated against. We have no access to public transport.

PARA.TAB: This fuel tax increase will also impact on tourism. It is a tax on tourism. At that committee hearing, Senator Schacht agreed that about 80 per cent of Australian tourists travel around Australia by motor vehicle and that the increase in petrol tax will increase the costs of people travelling to rural and regional Australia. But we were unable to elicit from Senator Schacht whether the Department of Tourism had done any work prior to the budget on just how fuel tax increases will impact on tourism in regional Australia.
However, Senator Schacht, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Bureau of Tourism Research will be conducting ongoing research and assessing the impact. That is part of its job. The results of that will be made available to government and to the parliament at the appropriate time.
He also said:
I would be surprised if the bureau did not assess the impact on regional tourism because so much of our tourism in Australia is regionally oriented.

On the basis of those answers, I am certainly looking forward to hearing from the Department of Tourism about its assessment of the impact of the increased fuel excise on regional tourism. In my own mind, I am quite sure that regional destinations which are a long way from the centres of population are going to suffer a severe impact because of the added cost of fuel.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday afternoon I listened with interest to Senator Coulter when he made his contribution to this debate. TALK.START.PARA: —Leave it to the Greens.

PARA.TAB: Later on in the debate on this matter we had a contribution from Senator Margetts. I am sorry that Senator Chamarette has left the chamber because the Greens are very concerned about the impact of the budget on low income families. If they are so concerned about the impact on low income families, then I am quite sure they will see their way clear to support us when we try to make sure that these increases in fuel tax do not take effect.

Senator Margetts spent a lot of time talking about the effect lead will have on the environment. Senator Coulter did also. The one thing that they did not mention, and it has been admitted by government ministers, is that the use of a fuel tax is entirely a revenue raiser. I do not know why they do not admit that it is a revenue raiser. It has nothing to do with lead in the environment and it has nothing to do with making sure that the money raised by the increase in the fuel tax is used for improving the environment. It would do Senator Margetts well to consider the impact this increase in fuel tax would have on regional areas particularly in her home state of Western Australia, where people have such vast distances to travel.

Senator Margetts also indicated that she did not really know what she was talking about when she said that she did not want `any old dirty cars dumped in this country'—I think that was the phrase she used. It has been mentioned before in this debate that we went through that last May when consideration was given to the importation into Australia of second-hand cars which use lead free petrol. That legislation was knocked out because it was considered that it would have too big an impact on the car industry. Now we have the situation where the government is thinking about reconsidering its position—or so we have heard—on the importation of second-hand cars which use lead free petrol. Senator Margetts need not be concerned about old cars being dumped in Australia. If cars do come here they are going to be five years old or less and will use unleaded petrol.
I also listened with interest to Senator Cooney. Last night he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The argument we have heard tonight is really an argument that there should be no taxes at all on any activity or on any particular person.
Senator Sherry injected and said:
That is the Liberal Party's new policy.

Let me tell the government that I and my colleagues in the coalition realise that taxes have to be raised and that every government must have revenue with which to carry out its program. We also understand that taxes form the basis for raising revenue. It is important to make sure when raising revenue that the taxes that are raised are equitably shared. Raising this massive new amount through an increase in fuel tax means that the people who can least afford it are the ones who are going to be hit the most.

PARA.TAB: I am quite sure that even some members of the government would agree that this increase in fuel tax is going to impact unfairly on those people who live distances from the major cities. It is going to impact unfairly on those people in rural communities who use fuel extensively and who are already having a tough time trying to make their businesses survive. These people have to use fuel in their farming enterprises and in every aspect of the running of their businesses. They are the ones who have been having the toughest time in the past few years with droughts and low commodity prices. They are the people who are going to bear the brunt of the increase in the fuel tax.

I urge the government and I particularly urge the Greens and the Democrats to consider their position carefully when it comes to voting on this bill. I am quite sure that in their own minds they do not wish to hurt those people who can least afford it. The one way that they can make sure that they do not get hurt is by making sure that the increases that are proposed in the fuel tax and fuel excise will not be passed.
