PARA.TAB: The explanatory notes indicate that these bills will result in the cost of leaded petrol increasing by 3c per litre from 18 August and a further 2c on top of that from February 1994 and again in August 1994. The cost of unleaded petrol will rise 3c per litre from 18 August and thereafter by 1c in February and August 1994. That will be the effect of these bills should they be passed this afternoon. The bills are the most significant and controversial part of the budget, as I mentioned before. As Senator Ferguson mentioned, they are nothing more than a fundraising exercise by the government. They do nothing more than fund the government's already bloated spending programs.

The government sought economic credibility, during the election and since, with a plan to reduce the budget deficit to one per cent of GDP before 1996. It has now revised that figure to 1.3 per cent of GDP before 1996. The parliament and the markets await the next revision of that budget plan before the next budget in June. A revision will surely come, as the cornerstone of the government's so-called plan is based on the very spurious figures delivered by Treasury, yet again, regarding world economic growth.

In truth, world economic growth will not be achieved. One of our major trading partners, Japan, forecasts zero GDP growth this financial year and in the coming years. Western European countries continue to flounder below our budget forecast of 2.5 per cent growth in GDP. If the whole budget strategy is based on recovery in the world recession, then the budget was a failure the very night it was brought down. The bills before the Senate seem to have created pain for no gain at all and, as far as the government deficit reduction plan is concerned, this budget amounts to nought.

The rural sector has had to take the brunt of just about every single budget—at least every budget in the last three years, during the recessionary times—that this government has handed down. It should be remembered that in the past decade the Australian rural sector has never really taken in the effects of those boom conditions that the stock market, the entrepreneurs, the manufacturers and the mining sector have all enjoyed. Any price rises that occurred in commodities for those brief moments in 1988-89 were never passed down to the farm gate. Much of the profit was simply taken by the middlemen, the agents, the abattoir workers, the transporters or the exporters. But I stress that it never reached the farm gate. Because of this, there really is great social tension in rural Australia today. Rural Australia wants to know why it has to take another massive rise in petrol at a time when household incomes are at poverty levels and at a time when the export prices for commodities have collapsed to their lowest levels in a decade.

I refer to the Commonwealth Bank's commodity price index, which has plunged by some 4.2 per cent in the last month. This is the lowest level on record, below the trough reached at the depths of the 1986 banana republic currency crisis. This is despite the value of Australian mineral exports increasing by five per cent. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics reveals that it is only the tumbling Australian dollar which has been cushioning the blow to the national income of sliding commodity prices and weak world demand. The rural sector, quite frankly, is being trashed. The anger about the deals done between the government and the Democrats with respect to petrol can be compared with the anger that the Italians showed towards Mussolini and his mistress.

There is fast becoming a north and south divide in this country, as there was in America. The rural sector of Australia has become very much the defeated and the exploited south, with its carpetbaggers and all. The government continues to drive old Dixie down. I ask honourable senators to consider these figures: the latest DEET figures show that in my state of Victoria unemployment has doubled in some of the main regional cities. In Ballarat it is 18 per cent; in Mildura it is 18 per cent; in Maryborough it is 22 per cent; and in Morwell it is 16 per cent. The city of Melbourne has plateaued at a state average of around 12 per cent while rural unemployment continues to rise.

Moreover, in my state of Victoria, the average rural income for a family—not a single income—is $28,000, and one should bear in mind the very high costs of living in the country areas. In the city of Melbourne, it is $40,000 and in the city of Canberra it happens to be $50,000. At the lower end of the scale in rural Victoria, those who earn less than $16,000 make up 23 per cent, while in Melbourne it is 12 per cent. At the higher end of the scale, families in rural Victoria with incomes above $60,000 make up nine per cent. In Melbourne it is 21 per cent. So the gulf between income and employment is greater than it really should be. A gulf really has opened up. As I said before, we are becoming a north and south divide.

The difference in the cost of fuel, leaded or unleaded, between country and city before this extra impost was already around 20c a litre. This new tax, as described in the explanatory memorandum, will place it well and truly above that 20c per litre difference between city and country. The effects of this have been well described by my colleagues in the chamber this evening and yesterday. They included an added $20 million to farm costs, an extra $9.1 million to the operating costs of rail authorities and an extra $3 to the average weekly shopping basket of $70.

The facts are that these price increases will cause a disaster in the rural sector and will affect the rural sector much more than metropolitan areas. If these prices continue to rise in the country and if fuel and transport costs continue to rise, I wonder if it is not a good idea to take up the Industry Commission's recommendation and introduce a toll system. It does sound, at first blush, very unpalatable, but if it means relief from excise tax for rural people, then the day for consideration is drawing very close indeed.

We are fed up with reading about harbour tunnels in Sydney, ring roads in Melbourne, underpasses, overpasses and cross-passes in our major cities, while potholes and dirt roads are the order of the day in rural Australia. The National Road Transport Commission has reported that non-metropolitan areas account for some 40 per cent of Victoria's petrol prices. Despite being major players in the market, rural communities and businesses receive no discounts and even pay freight costs which come free of charge to city customers. At times of heavy discounting in metropolitan areas, the price gap in the country has been larger still.

While the government simply uses excise tax to raise revenue, the oil companies are also guilty of using high fuel prices against rural communities, businesses and farmers to subsidise their price wars in the city. The most effective way to restore fair petrol pricing between country and metropolitan areas would be to introduce a uniform terminal gate price. Certainly such an idea is worth looking at.

Under the terminal gate price system, as recommended by the Victorian state government rural committee, oil companies would be required to sell petrol at uniform prices. The only difference between rural petrol prices and metropolitan petrol prices would be the transport costs—that is fair enough—not the added cost that usually goes on to the rural petrol pumps to pay for the discounting that savages the city. Any discounting in the city would be passed on to the country with only the transport costs added. Where there is a discount in the city, there would be a discount in the country. That is fair. This is a worthy policy to consider in order to restore equity in rural Australia.

Last month's budget has struck at the heart of rural Australia. It has placed another hurdle in the path of rural people as they struggle to survive. For the government speakers in this debate, the increase in petrol, diesel and other fuel prices was simply a revenue raiser and nothing more. The pathetic attempt to sell increases in fuel taxes for environmental or health reasons cannot be taken seriously. I think Senator Coulter would be the only one who takes that seriously. Certainly for the rural sector these taxes have presented another unanticipated blow to their livelihood.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. We oppose aspects of this government's budget, particularly the fuel excise increases, for two reasons. First, the government has no mandate to introduce new taxes. On the contrary, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) promised as law—l-a-w—that there would be legislated tax cuts. Secondly, these increases are bad economics. The budget, as shown in the government's own papers, will not work—not one job created and inflation taking off. So much for the primary objective of this budget being jobs.

PARA.TAB: The fuel tax increases represent an assault on Australia's primary producers and economic wellbeing in pursuit of a blatant revenue grab. Every petrol station is now a sub-agency of the Australian Taxation Office. Perhaps the smiling face of the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr John Carmody, should be plastered on each bowser. When people go to their local self-service station, they are always forking out to the government.

Fuel keeps the motor of the Australian economy ticking over. Fuel is essential for economic growth. Fuel costs are the lead in the saddlebag of small business. And talking of lead, I can assure the Senate that it is not the lead in the fuel that hurts small business either.

Growth in small business is the only way we will ever begin to solve the unemployment crisis facing this country. This government's modus operandi is just to cast around like a drunk in the dark for another method of raising funds for its profligate behaviour. The government said nothing about raising taxes during the election. Indeed, it said that it would not raise taxes.

The FitzGerald report gives us due warning of what this government will do. It tells us to watch out for higher indirect taxes, for a Labor style consumption tax, for a wealth tax and for an inheritance tax—whatever tax one names, FitzGerald has given this government the chance to put a smile on Mr Dawkins's face. It has now been revealed that Labor's indirect tax increase will raise more than the GST package would have raised—but without the compensation package that we proposed. This government is economically incompetent, a government of total dishonesty.

The health and wealth of this nation rides on industry, especially primary industry. One has only to look at the small businesses one knows to call to mind the old expression that one person's wage increase is another person's job. Well, this government's indirect tax increases will have a similar effect. The morning after the budget was brought down, a small businessman that I know said that the fuel excise would increase his monthly expenses by about $1,200. He immediately put off his junior. That is a living example of why this indirect tax is absolutely killing small business.

Yet the Keating-Dawkins duo cannot see this. In fact, since the budget was handed down, they have continued to show that they are both devoid of economic commonsense. They do not understand business. In fact, it is probably a long time since either of them have actually paid for fuel. They are out of touch, despite the recent claims from caucus that they have pulled the happy duo into line.

What about the recent report that Mr Dawkins has been smiling a lot lately? Somebody said to me that he has probably realised his economic management is a bit of a joke. People should realise that Labor has taxed and taxed and taxed fuel to the point where industry is crippled and rural Australia is struggling under the weight.

If we look at what the 55 per cent increase in fuel oil excise will do to Australia's shipping industry, it demonstrates the irresponsibility of these changes. Within 12 months the additional cost to the Australian coastal shipping industry will be $16.1 million annually. This equates to an additional $790 per day to operate a ship, or almost $300,000 per ship per year.

This comes at a time when the Shipping Industry Reform Authority and the Maritime Union of Australia have reached an agreement to remove 111 crew berths from Australian coastal shipping. The effect of the increase in excise is equivalent in cost to putting another 146 crew berths back on board each year. Four years of micro-economic reform have been wiped out by this iniquitous tax. This is sheer economic stupidity.

In addition, under Fightback an average ship would have been about $300,000 per annum better off through the reforms and savings that we proposed. The differential is therefore nearly $600,000 per ship. That would have been real micro-economic reform. People's memories are short, but the great majority of what we proposed in Fightback was right for each and every Australian—including the little people whom this government has forgotten about—and right and fair for Australia.

The Nabalco aluminium smelter in the Northern Territory stands to lose the most from the increase in duty on fuel oil. That company will see its pre-tax results plummet by $25 million a year as a result of the increase from about 5c to 10c a litre by August next year. Why do such companies bother to try to compete? What sort of message does that give to potential investors? I know that I would be looking elsewhere.

There will be no more aluminium smelters built in Australia—they will all go overseas—or Nabalco will just sell bauxite unprocessed. So much for value adding! More than 60 per cent excisable petroleum products are consumed by business and industry, so the rises in excise rates will reduce international competitiveness and add to business costs. Fuel is a cost on exports that distorts the level playing field to our disadvantage. Fuel excise makes us less competitive. The effects will be most profound in agriculture and mining, Australia's major export industries.
This government tells us it is about jobs. What a joke! Its own budget papers show that there will be no growth in employment during 1993-94.

TALK.START.PARA: —None at all.

—Senator O'Chee confirms it. The budget papers tell a lot. The projected inflation rate of 3.5 per cent will be a direct result of these indirect tax increases. Further, its fuel increases will see one in every six truck drivers thrown out of his job. The fuel cost for one truck alone will jump $6,400 per year, while the sales tax on maintenance items will cost an extra $2,400.
—An extra cost for the farmers and extra costs for town and country people.

—Absolutely. For all country people the burdens are unbearable. Rural Australia has again been targeted by this government. Almost everything comes into the country areas on the back of a truck. A trolley load of groceries will cost about $3 more. It will cost motorists $4 a week more to fill up. It is just a case of ordinary Australians being used as a tax revenue milch cow.

PARA.TAB: Industry will see relocation to major cities as a more attractive option so as to avoid increasing transport costs. So much for value adding in country Australia. When Mr Crean talks about value adding, he, of all people, as former president of the ACTU, knows more than anybody and can take much of the blame for Australian manufacturers voting with their feet and going overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bill Kelty can take some of the blame too.

—He is the apprentice. This increase in fuel costs will have two effects. The rural areas will go into further economic decline and the cities will feel the increased strain on their urban environments. I am sorry that Senators Chamarette and Margetts are not here because they would be interested in that. The people who live in the poorest parts of Australia are hurt the most. People living in the country rely so much more heavily on transport than do city dwellers. People with the lowest median income, country people, suffer the most.

PARA.TAB: A recent survey of average distances from services of families living on farms and in capital cities demonstrates the magnitude of the impact of fuel tax increases. The survey revealed that the average private distance travelled by farm families is just over 31,000 kilometres per year compared to just over 19,000 kilometres per year for a capital city family. On this basis the budget increase will cost a farm family about $160 a year extra—$60 more than their city cousins. Add to that the fact that country fuel is more expensive anyway and it makes the position even worse. Economic modelling by the Industry Commission of the effects of fuel taxes on the economy shows that these increases in fuel excise will reduce economic growth by 0.3 per cent, reduce exports by 1.4 per cent and increase unemployment by 0.4 per cent. On average they will reduce net farm profit by 10.4 per cent.

This comes on the top of the most appalling farm trading conditions we have ever seen. Figures from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics show that during the past three years farmers have accumulated massive losses. These have included losses of $62,000 for all broadacre farmers; losses of $18,000 for those with wheat and other crops; losses of $51,000 for mixed farmers; an incredible loss of $107,000 for specialist wool producers; losses of $43,000 for beef growers; and losses of $68,000 for cattle and sheep producers.

In industries which are heavily dependent on transport the effects will be even more pronounced. The support we received from farmers and farm organisations when they understood the fuel cost savings under Fightback showed the importance of fuel to the farm sector. Under Fightback the transport sector alone would have reaped savings of just over $2 billion a year, and these were official Treasury figures. The fuel tax rise, coupled with the $600 million cut in road funding, is a double whammy for country people. The slashing of road funding means that the black spot program, which was a major contributor to road safety and employment in country areas, was not renewed. This is nothing short of irresponsible. This is politically and morally wrong.

Statistics from the Federal Office of Road Safety indicate that for every $44 million of road funding one life has been saved. With this savage increase in fuel tax, accompanied by cuts in road funding, the family motorist will suffer—the low income family motorist worst of all—while the government allows the road that they travel on to fall further into disrepair. Under this government the petrol bowser has become an intrinsic part of funding its unrealistic policies.

In response to a question from me recently, Senator Collins admitted that when the government came to power in 1983 over $6.50 out of every $10 raised through fuel tax was spent on Commonwealth road funding. The budget papers now reveal that by 1994-95 this will have fallen to $1 out of every $10 raised. I am sure the electorates in country and coastal New South Wales would like to know that—the electors in Richmond, Page, Calare, New England, Hunter and beyond. The government has also offloaded its responsibility in road funding by untying the states grants and therefore local government grants, meaning that there is no guarantee that these funds will actually find their way to road funding at all.

Under Fightback the coalition would have saved the private motorist 19c per litre and the business motorist 26c per litre, while maintaining road funding at current levels in real terms. In our vast country fuel excise to the value of about $8 billion would have been returned to ordinary Australians dependent on the car.

Low income earners, pensioners, unemployed people, battling farmers and students will be hit the hardest by the government's differential on leaded and unleaded fuel. Sixty per cent of cars driven by country people use leaded fuel. These people, through no fault of their own, will now pay 33.5c a litre in tax on the fuel that they buy. Unlike their city cousins, country residents have limited access to public transport. The simple fact is that everything from food to machinery in country areas comes in on the back of a truck.

I could not believe the recent reported comments by Reserve Bank chief, Bernie Fraser, who said he would prefer petrol to be taxed rather than food. Of course, fuel prices impact on food in country areas because everything comes in on the back of a semi-trailer. His partisanship on tax and budget matters generally is really uncalled for.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you that this budget, as far as country people are concerned, is clearly from a government out of touch. It will be country people who will be particularly savage on this government when they next have the chance to vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues have spoken with great eloquence, compassion and conviction about the stupidity of a government that seeks to increase the cost of transport in a country with one of the highest foreign debts in the world, an enormously high level of unemployment, and a country that is totally dependent on cheap transport costs if it is to be internationally competitive.

PARA.TAB: I want to confine my comments to the impact of this fuel increase on the boating industry of Australia. The boating industry, boat owners and boat users are the forgotten people when it comes to this iniquitous government tax grab. I want to speak on behalf of the millions of Australians who engage in boating as part of their normal leisure pursuits.

It is entirely predictable that such people would be forgotten by this government. This government sits here in splendid isolation in the artificial inland city of Canberra. The government has been here for 11 years with all its bureaucrats devising these incredible taxes on ordinary Australians, forgetting that ordinary Australians live by the sea. One cannot even have power boats in Canberra. The government and its bureaucrats sit here and they never see a power boat. The public servants and the politicians would not know the effect that such a tax will have on the millions of Australians who actually use boats, because in this town people are restricted to sailing. The only power boat politicians and public servants ever see here is a ferry.

This is a very important issue. It is not just the economic impact. The fact is that boating and fishing are two of the great leisure activities of Australians. Leisure is one of the real factors in the effective productivity of a nation. I think we forget that if a nation is to be productive and internationally competitive, its leisure activities are important. Boating and fishing are enjoyed by millions of Australians.

This government probably is not aware—maybe some of its advisers are not aware—that most boats use petrol motors. They have an outboard on the back. One has to put petrol in it to make it go. Further, they just about all use leaded petrol. One of the most iniquitous things in this whole deal is that, under the guise of protecting the environment from the dreaded lead, leaded petrol is going to be made that much dearer. That is the latest treachery that has been played out on the people who indulge in boating and fishing.

This is all about this government attacking the people it claims to represent. My colleagues have spoken about the fact that it is lower income Australians who are stuck with vehicles, made expensive by other policies of this government, that use leaded petrol. They are the ones being hit by this latest tax. It so happens that the people who use boats and indulge in boating in this country—as I say, there are millions of them—are, by and large, middle and lower income people.

One of the delusions of the Labor Party is that it is the millionaires who sit around and drink wine, so it taxes the wine industry. It probably thinks, if it thinks about boat owners at all, that they are all rich. They are not; I can assure the government of that. They are ordinary Australians escaping from the misery of life under this government by getting out on the water. These people were deceived. There was no warning about any increase in petrol prices prior to the election. These people have been deceived by this government.

As I said, boating and fishing are pursuits enjoyed traditionally by the families of Australia. Most of our immigrants probably came here by boat. The first ones did and they have been coming here by boat for a long time. This is an island nation. We indulge our pursuit of boating because we love it and because we live by the sea.

For a lot of these Australians, life has got very tough. We live in a country with very high unemployment, very high crime rates, moral breakdown and high interest rates. The economy has been in an awful mess for a very long time. A lot of Australians, therefore, seek some escape from this misery by indulging in boating and fishing—pursuits which require petrol. But there is absolutely no escape from this government. This government bludgeons them with a hike in the petrol price. Every time they go down to their boat ramp, Paul Keating is standing on the ramp, ready to take his cut of the increase in the petrol price. The really terrible thing about this is that the further out people go to sea to try to escape Paul Keating and his tax, the more tax they will pay, because the further out they go, the more petrol they will use and the more Paul will take from them.

Boat owners and users are already paying 26c per litre in petrol tax to this government; they pay an average of another 7c per litre to state governments to run their boats and this government is going to put on another 5c or 7c. This will have a dramatic effect on the capacity of Australians who love their boats and using them.

As I said before, putting the extra tax on leaded over unleaded petrol is particularly vicious in relation to boat owners and boat users. Over 90 per cent of outboards in use can use only leaded petrol. It is a fact that only the most modern of outboard motors can use unleaded petrol.

Of course, if you are a boat owner and you see that the government is going to tax leaded petrol much more than it is going to tax unleaded, you might think, `Well, perhaps I'd better go down and buy one of these new outboard motors'. As soon as you walk in the door the boat dealer says, `Look, I'm sorry but the federal government has got a 20 per cent tax on outboard motors. It has just gone up to 21 per cent and it is going to go up to 22 per cent'. So there is absolutely no incentive to buy a motor which will take unleaded petrol, which this government says it wants to encourage. It is another classic example of the government having utterly contradictory policies which tear at each other.

The average age of outboard motors is over 10 years. We have heard evidence about the age of the car fleet in this country and why it is the voters that Labor claims to represent who are going to be most hurt by this tax increase, but the same thing applies to outboard motors. As I say, that is a direct reflection of the fact that boating is an activity primarily indulged in by middle and lower income Australian families.

It gets even worse. In order to be able to have a simple tin boat with an outboard motor on the back, a lot of ordinary Australians have sacrificed buying a new car. They keep the old car just that little bit longer because they spend their extra dollars on their boating activities. So they do not have new cars that take unleaded petrol. They can be seen down at the ramp driving in with their 15-year-old Holdens with the boat on the back. Now they are going to get slugged there. It is going to cost them that much more just to tow the boat to the ramp, before they even put the boat in the water with Paul Keating standing there ready to take the money off them as they drive away in their boat.

PARA.TAB: I guess a lot of Australians would be unaware of the size of the recreational boating and fishing industry. It is a very big industry. There are about 500,000 registered boats in Australia. About four and a half million Australians have voluntarily expressed their love of fishing and of course many of them do it in boats. There are 80,000 people employed in this industry. TALK.START.PARA: —Where would you cut?

—I have a few ideas on that, but I am talking about cutting the government's pernicious taxation of the millions of Australians who enjoy boating. All boat owners have been deceived by this government. This government deliberately led voters to believe that it could have the income tax cuts which were promised on the spur of the moment in One Nation without any increases in taxation in other areas of tax. They were grossly deceived by this government.

PARA.TAB: It reminds me that in 1978 I was a junior research officer in the federal secretariat of the Liberal Party when the then Fraser liberal government decided, for reasons of its own, that it could not honour promises made in the 1977 federal election which, everyone will recall, involved a fistful of dollars. Having been centrally involved in that campaign, I remember it well. Regrettably, that government in May 1978 broke its promises in relation to various aspects of tax. As the officer responsible for polling, I was more aware than anyone of the dramatic effect on the standing of that government as a result of its breaking of promises on taxation.

The Australian people believe in a fair go; they believe that their governments have to be honest and up-front with them. That government was perceived not to have been honest with the Australian people and to have breached its faith with the Australian people, and it suffered accordingly. There was a dramatic decline in the polls; it stayed behind Labor all the way through from that period; it managed to recover in time for the 1980 federal election and scrape over the line; and, as soon as that election was over, it fell behind the Labor Party once again because of that very fundamental breach of faith in 1978.

It is my view—and I think the Labor Party is perhaps too close to it to understand it—that this government has just now gone through that same experience. This is 1978 for the Labor Party. That breach of faith in relation to taxation will be its undoing and I do not believe that this government will ever recover from it.

Boat owners of Australia have been cheated by this government; they will now be paying much more for their boating pursuits. As I think Senator O'Chee mentioned, car owners may get something back for the tax they pay, but nothing like a fair return. In some countries, of course, the tax paid on petrol is more than matched by the money the collecting government puts into roads and facilities for motorists; that is not the case in this country, but at least motorists get some return for their dollars. Where is the return for the boat owners of Australia from the millions and millions of dollars they pay to this government in tax?

This government cannot provide roads or their equivalent; the federal government, to my knowledge, does not provide any facilities for the boat owners of Australia. It is take, take, take on one of the great leisure pursuits of Australians. Boat owners get nothing in return for the taxes they pay to this government. They are going to be paying millions and millions of dollars more, so their capacity to escape from the rigours of life under Labor in this country is even further restricted. They are, indeed, the people who have been forgotten by this government.

I have sought this opportunity to put their case on the record to add to the plight of the millions of Australians in rural areas who, as my colleagues have described, will suffer so much damage from this government's actions, not the least of which will be the damage to the capacity of Australian industry to keep its costs low and compete in international marketplaces which will be the consequence of this ridiculous tax increase.

Again, we have a government that tries to dress up tax increases with some flavour of the month, politically correct idea. We saw it in relation to the wine tax and the argument, `Oh well, we have to maintain equity with beer and spirits; they're alcoholic drinks. So let's ignore the effects of the tax on wine in relation to that industry; let's just stick to this argument about equity'—and of course `equity' is a nice, mushy, politically correct word.

We have exactly the same argument in relation to this desperation grab by the government for another $1 billion from the Australian taxpayers: `How can we dress this one up? Let's put a green garb over this particular measure; let's tell the Australian people that we're not really interested in taxing them more, we are interested in saving their children from lead poisoning'. I have yet to see any evidence of children dying in the streets from lead poisoning. But this government will resort to the most awful propaganda methods to take over $1 billion from Australians in a country so vast that it relies on cheap transport to transport goods and people and remain internationally competitive. TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. There is no doubt that the government's increases in fuel taxes will significantly impact on people and families in rural and regional areas and on those on low incomes. However, the coalition's support for the government's irresponsible income tax cuts has greatly restricted the options available to reduce the impact of increased petrol excise as it is a major ingredient in paying for those tax cuts. To fully compensate is virtually impossible and, in any case, compensation measures are imprecise. However, given that we are stuck with the income tax cuts, there is little alternative.

PARA.TAB: Some weeks ago, the National Farmers Federation recognised the link between the tax cuts and the inability of the government and others to give the kind of relief which is required, and it urged the coalition not to continue to support the tax cuts which are being given. But its appeal was to no avail.

The Australian Council of Social Service said that fuel and sales tax rises will impact more strongly on urban fringe dwellers and especially on people who live in regional and rural Australia. Fuel rises will have an added impact on basic costs of living in these areas because of the effect of added freight costs. I might add to that the concern which has been expressed to me by charities such as Meals-on-Wheels and the Blue Nurses who depend very heavily on motor vehicles to deliver the services which are so needed within our community.

The Australian Democrats have already assisted country people to a far greater extent than anything the coalition has done so far by negotiating a reduction in the fuel tax hike from 10c per litre down to 7c per litre, and by ensuring that some of the money gained from the tax rise will be spent on what it is intended for—namely, addressing the impact of lead on Australians and our environment. Senator Coulter has explained our position on this and those negotiations continue. To reduce the fuel tax increase further than has already been achieved will simply put a large hole in the budget deficit—and that is the dilemma we face.

Prior to the last election, the Australian Democrats announced a policy which included increases in petrol excise; that policy was contained in our Getting to Work document. It was a balanced approach which sought to bring together job creation and environmental responsibility. In contrast, at the time I was horrified by the Fightback proposal to slash the petrol excise and thus guarantee that our cities' roads would continue to be choked with cars. I believe this to be environmental vandalism.

I am glad of the opportunity to refute also some of the misrepresentation of Democrat policy made by the coalition during the last election. I am minded to say that having the coalition try to explain our policy is about as useful as having Saddam Hussein explain US policy on the Gulf war to the Iraqi people. So let me put on record what Getting to Work is all about; there are a number of basic assumptions. We believe that in terms of a fuel excise policy there is a need to balance health concerns, environmental responsibility, economic stability, job creation and debt reduction—and I believe that in our document we did all of those things.

There is a need to reduce the number of motor vehicles on our city and suburban roads. There is a need to create work in new and environmentally friendly industries. There is a need to replace our dependence on fossil fuels. We believe that it is right and just to use the excise on fuel to accomplish these goals. In fact, we proposed an even higher rate of excise than the one in the measure before us. But it was a proposal for a higher rate of excise balanced with suitable measures to compensate rural industries and rural communities.

One of our proposals was to balance the hike in petrol excise with a cancellation of registration and third party fees. We would replace these with a standard nation-wide scheme. The cost of owning a motor vehicle would be cheaper, but the cost of using that motor vehicle over a certain distance would become more expensive. By our calculations, that crossover point was 18,000 kilometres. However, in recognition that rural communities often drive great distances—and one study has set an average for rural families at 31,000 kilometres per year—we proposed that a full study of rural needs and costs, as well as measures to compensate, be carried out before imposing any higher excise. We believe this is the kind of process that the government ought to have put in place before introducing this measure. So we agree with the coalition in its stated fact that this will impact seriously on rural and regional families.

We believe that the funds created by the higher excise also ought to be used to assist the transfer from dependence on fossil fuel to use of alternative renewable energy sources. My colleague Senator Coulter has already explained the work that we have done in replacing some of the fuel with ethanol. This is a job creation measure. At Manildra, in New South Wales, and certainly at certain points in Queensland, jobs would be created if this industry were enhanced in this way.

We also urge the provision of funding to upgrade public transport to assist both city and country people. We certainly would not be moving headlong to close down many of our railways, as both the coalition and the government have done in the past. This is the basis on which we have built our response to the whole idea of an increased excise on petrol.

I would like to put on the record some other measures which would be feasible in reducing the extra costs associated with living in non-metropolitan areas. One possible option is to resurrect the petroleum product freight subsidisation scheme. This scheme, which has been around in a number of forms since 1965, subsidises the freight cost on petrol to remote areas. Currently it subsidises only those freight costs which are greater than approximately 15c per litre. That helps virtually nobody. It currently costs the government only about $3 million a year. At one stage in 1981-82 the differential between city and country was 0.44c per litre, and the cost for that year was $147.5 million—obviously a much more significant attempt to address the differential.

Another measure which could be considered is increasing the zone rebate for income tax and the remote area allowance paid to DSS recipients. We have put forward these and other measures which would enable country people to reduce their costs.

We believe that one measure which could be introduced is an increase in the sales tax on energy inefficient cars. Whilst the argument would be put that rural people need powerful cars to travel on the highways, an extra tax could be justified on at least large capacity engines. Tying sales tax levels to fuel efficiency has been promoted by us for some time. An extra tax on large capacity engines could raise money to offset some of the above compensation measures or it could be made revenue neutral by a related reduction in tax levels on small fuel efficient cars.

Removing registration fees and covering the cost by increasing the petrol excise would more adequately address the costs of road usage, according to those who use it most. Farmers who have to pay large registration fees for machinery which is driven relatively small distances around the farm and rarely on the road would be much better off.

Let me briefly address road transport. In this place a lot has been made of the increase in the cost of a shopping trolley of goods, which I have heard put at various amounts. One amount quoted is $3 every time the shopping trolley goes to the checkout counter. We would question the calculation of that amount; however, accepting that there is an increase in the shopping trolley cost, this means that increased freight costs have been passed on to the consumer. It seems strange to us that the road transport industry would then claim that it will have to bear the increased fuel excise on at least that proportion of the increase which is passed on. There is an inconsistency there.

Let me address the differential between rural and city fuel prices. I am aware of a great inequity in fuel prices which people in non-metropolitan areas are subject to. Many studies have shown that the differential in petrol prices between city and country areas is far more than it should be. In effect, country people are subsidising city people's fuel. Effective price control mechanisms are difficult, as state governments have jurisdiction over much of this area, but they certainly would correct a very large injustice.

I know that Labor and the coalition are averse to government intervention in the operation of the market, so it makes it difficult—and sometimes impossible—for workable measures to be put in place to ensure that city people pay a fair price for petrol. But I believe this is a point at which those measures ought to be implemented.

In South Australia there is a 3c per litre fuel freight rebate scheme, yet often there is up to a 16c differential between city and country prices. It is obvious that there is a need to take account of the misuse by oil companies of the fuel freight rebate. The government promised during the election to commission an independent review of tax imposts on the road transport industry. It is important that this review be held as soon as possible.

Farm families drive an average of 31,000 kilometres per year, compared with 19,000 kilometres per year for city families. This means an extra $2 to $3 per week in petrol alone for rural families. The Democrats have a longstanding policy objective enshrined in our constitution to stem and reverse the flow of population from rural and provincial areas to the cities. Even if these proposals positively discriminate in favour of rural dwellers, they are justifiable in view of this important objective.

Even with those rural people who do use less fuel than city dwellers, it does not negate the fact that their options to use other means of transport are far fewer than those available to city people. It is reasonable to assume that increased fuel costs will impact more on the cost of living in non-metropolitan areas because of the increased freight costs to such areas. This cost should be recognised and compensation should be made available.

Over the coming months, the Democrats will continue to pursue possible options and will pressure the government to address the impact of its policies on rural communities, particularly as part of discussions about next year's budget. For the present, we intend to urge the government to initiate a proper lead abatement strategy, which has been a condition of our cooperation on this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two key issues in this debate that are highlighted for the Greens and they really expose a need for a much broader approach to public policy. The issues that are conflicting in the approach that has been taken by the government are social equity and environmental protection. Neither issue has been adequately addressed in the government's approach to reducing the amount of lead in petrol or to the fuel tax increases.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate to commence discussion with an examination of the environmental implications of this bill. Ostensibly, the proposal to increase the price of leaded petrol is designed to act as a market mechanism to encourage car owners to change to unleaded petrol wherever possible. This is undoubtedly a laudable aim, given the growing body of evidence that points to the detrimental health effects of lead on our children. We must, however, acknowledge the need to address the broader issue of the environmental and health implications of all vehicles emissions.

There is a danger that, by concentrating only on the lead aspect of vehicle emissions, we may exacerbate the broader vehicle emission problems. There is scientific evidence which suggests that the adjustment of engines in older vehicles to allow them to use unleaded petrol will result in increased emissions of carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide and other vehicle pollutants that contribute to the growing air pollution problems in our cities as well as to the global greenhouse problem.

The approach that has been taken by the government also fails to address the more fundamental and long-term aspects of the problem of petrol usage. A price differential, as we have mentioned earlier, is useless if we perpetuate the urban sprawl that now dominates our cities and if we fail to provide planning options such as public transport, cycleways, urban villages and the like to encourage people out of cars.

In the United States, for example, studies have found that general emission levels have been maintained at high levels despite a reduction in the emission levels in individual vehicles. This is due to the fact that the average urban miles travelled by vehicles is increasing substantially. An appropriate analogy can be drawn with alcohol levels in beer. If a beer drinker switched to a low alcohol beer but increased the amount of beer consumed, it is likely that the level of alcohol in the blood could remain the same as that when consuming a lower level of high alcohol beer.

The question of social equity is vitally important. From the beginning, there has been nothing equitable about car ownership. The rich own new cars; the poorer people own old ones. Older cars cost more to run and are less safe and efficient. In the last decade the rich have realised that there is much to be said for inner city living. There are more services available, more sociability, a sense of character and amenity. As the rich moved into the cities, demographers pointed out that the poor have been pushed to the urban fringes. The urban sprawl which fits so well with car use disadvantages those without cars. It also makes provision of services and public transport outside the city core increasingly expensive. Without public transport the poor are doubly disadvantaged and so buy old cars and the vicious cycle takes another turn.

This bill does nothing about those fundamental problems. Cars are made more expensive to operate but no alternatives are provided. Funding for alternatives is being cut; the poor are made poorer. The answer is not, as Senator Chapman suggested yesterday, that this country desperately needs cheaper cars. That is not an adequate solution.

A market based approach to this problem that does not contain measures to alleviate the impact of increased prices on those with low incomes is unjust. It is acknowledged that many of those who own the older cars that use leaded petrol are low income earners. These people are also often forced to live on the fringes of cities and, as a consequence, need to travel greater distances for work or social reasons. Not only will these people have to bear the additional costs associated with increased petrol prices but, if they wish to avoid that price difference, they will need to either buy a new car or modify their existing vehicles to allow them to use unleaded petrol.

Beyond this—and the opposition speakers have referred to this consistently—there is the impact on the rural sector. While truck-in, truck-out rural towns do not foster local-regional development, there will be a major impact on these towns. Specific programs for rural development are also being cut along with many services such as schools, medical services and postal services, which are eroded within portfolios in the name of economic rationalisation. While not actually linking these issues to this bill, we feel that any government with integrity and the interests of ordinary people at heart cannot proceed with measures such as this unless it is also doing something to reduce the impact, through stimulating the local-regional economies that can reduce the dependency on long haul road freight.

In summary, the present package fails to satisfy us because, while it does address the environmental concerns that we have, it does not actually address the social equity impact of what basically amounts to revenue raising measures. Because of that, the Greens have provided, through Senator Margetts, the foreshadowed amendments. We believe that these amendments will at least use the gain in revenue that the government is earning through the increases in a way that people will benefit from rather than it simply going into revenue.

The government expects to realise over $800 million a year on the increase in petrol excise. It expects to realise about $175 million in additional income through the tax on leaded petrol. At the same time, it is cutting 57 per cent of its funding for programs that would improve the environmental and equity situation in relation to car use. The purpose of the amendments that are being put forward by Senator Margetts are to tie the government to positive action in implementing its own policy recommendations in relation to sustainable development and to establish standards so that problems such as the current lead emission crisis can be avoided in the future.

The contribution of 1c per litre to a trust fund would be about $160 million or 10 per cent of the cost of existing programs currently being cut. The lead levels set in our foreshadowed amendments are those agreed upon in the round table discussion between the department of the environment, the states and industry. The timetable is that agreed upon at that meeting.

We failed to enact standards on leaded petrol and lead petrol engines when other nations did; we are now paying the price. We must ensure that we do not fall so far behind by setting our standards for new car emissions and efficiency levels at the highest level demanded by other nations, especially by major markets such as the USA and the European Common Market. Not only will we benefit through reduced pollution and energy use, but our domestic industry will build to standards similar to those demanded by international markets.

As I have said before, car use is inherently inequitable. The poor are excluded from cars; the slightly better off have old, inefficient cars. Yet our cities are designed around car use and penalise those who do not own cars. The poorest increasingly find themselves marginalised in the outer fringes where transport lines are longest and both services and public transport are least available. Car use will not ever be made equitable or sustainable. The way to achieve both social and environmental objectives is through restructuring our cities to reduce the need for private cars. This was the clear conclusion of the government's ESD transport working group.

Senator Margetts has already mentioned the government's announcement that it will cut programs for urban development and public transport from $2.8 billion in 1992-93 to $1.2 billion in 1996-97. This is contrary to any attempt to adequately address the social or environmental effect of car use. It is a disgrace when the government is putting up petrol taxes and using environmental concerns as a justification.

US studies have shown that carbon taxes that go into general revenue cost 10 to 25 times more than the cost of programs aimed at directly reducing energy use to accomplish the same reduction. We may force some people out of cars but it will be neither fair nor efficient. Using a small part of the revenue on the same basis as road funding to directly address the need for urban restructuring is a simple solution. Rural areas will be hit disproportionately at a time when they are suffering cutbacks in many other areas. Rural development programs will be halved in the next four years. While reducing the dependency on long haul shipping is a valid goal, it will not be achieved simply by making it more expensive. Support for rural development, especially development of local regional industries to replace shipping, will generate employment while making communities more sustainable.

Rail and shipping are important factors and they will be impacted on by this bill. Coastal shipping is important to Australia and is under threat from ships which take in fuel in other Asian nations. This measure will not help to make shipping more efficient and competitive. Rail is important in improving the efficiency and safety of long haul freight, especially rural agricultural freight and urban public transport. These areas should be supported as more sustainable alternatives as they were targeted as important in the ESD transport recommendations. That is the reason why we have foreshadowed these amendments and I commend them to my colleagues.

We feel that there has to be some guarantee from the government that it will introduce measures that are more than simply revenue raising exercises. We believe that, if the public is to face an increase in the cost of petrol, we should be regulating the industry very strictly. The maximum allowable levels of lead in petrol should be set at 0.2 grams per litre and a clear schedule for phasing out leaded petrol should be established. The Senate should be satisfied that the federal government has used all means at its disposal to ensure compliance.

We also suggested in our amendments that fuel for sea freight and diesel for rail services should be exempted from the increases provided for in this bill. We would like the Australian Design Rules, embodying best world standard principles, to be incorporated in setting all emission levels for all new vehicles.

The government needs to implement a strategy that acknowledges these concerns. The lead abatement strategy, proposed by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly), is a partial approach to that problem. The amendments proposed by the Democrats and the Greens also attempt to address this. We welcome the support that any of those amendments may gain from the opposition and, we wish, from the government.

In looking at the petrol consumption in our community, we really want something that takes into consideration all factors, including environmental factors—that means reducing car use and consumption as well as taxing—and health and safety factors. We do not want to simply shift people from one fuel to another. The shift from leaded to unleaded petrol and the differential involved is a positive thing from the point of view of the Greens. I quote from an article by Newman and Kenworthy:

SPEECH.PARA: It now appears that removing lead from petrol is essential from a health and environmental perspective, beneficial in terms of energy and other emissions, and of marginal cost if not benefit to the motorist. One wonders if the past decade of intense controversy on this issue which has cost so much time, money and human energy, could have been considerably eased if the environmental perspective had been treated more credibly.
We do not believe that a levy is the best way to make the changes that are proposed unless they encompass a broadly based package on energy use. A levy on its own is not enough.

PARA.TAB: The Greens do support taxing energy. We feel that the full cost of our energy consumption in today's world is not being evaluated. Therefore, when the price goes up it is appropriate to remember that it is reflecting a cost that energy consumption has to the environment and to the health and safety of people. In July we believed that some such tax might be imposed. We wrote to the minister for the environment and said that we supported the possible introduction of an energy tax but were cautious about supporting an immediate increase in the price of leaded petrol because our principal concern was the potentially regressive impact of an energy tax or a price increase in leaded petrol. We felt that the government should take steps to reduce the negative impact on the poor and powerless before any new measures were introduced.

While we were very concerned, and still are, about the amount of lead in petrol and the harmful effect of this, especially on children, the onus needs to be on petroleum companies to reduce the amount of lead in petrol, particularly in Western Australia, which has the highest lead levels in Australia. We also support the introduction of a price differential to encourage drivers to switch to unleaded petrol. I wrote that letter on 30 July.

I felt that simply raising the petrol levy misses an opportunity to green the tax system as a whole. A broadly based energy tax, announced at the same time as the detail of the income tax cuts, would have been much more helpful in shifting taxes from income to the use of non-renewable resources—a very expensive use.

The Greens are in favour of taxes and charges that encourage more efficient resource use and reduce environmental degradation but these should be part of a socially responsible package to encourage energy conservation. A well constructed energy package could do this, reducing urban congestion and greenhouse emissions, and could also provide funds for improved government services for payment of public debt. However, money raised by the taxes should first be directed towards addressing energy and equity issues.

Sustainable development involves social justice as well as environmental concern. The Greens care for people as well as the planet. This means ensuring policies are equitable as well as ecologically and economically possible. While we support these bills, we express serious concerns over their impact, and that is why we have foreshadowed our amendments and we urge our colleagues to support them.

Mr Acting Deputy President, when the government initially presented its budget legislation to the parliament, as you will remember, many of the revenue raising measures were contained in one bill—the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. The coalition received advice from several eminent constitutional lawyers that the bill, if enacted, would be vulnerable to a successful challenge under section 55 of the constitution. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, of section 55. It states:
Laws imposing taxation shall deal only with the imposition of taxation, and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect.

Laws imposing taxation, except laws imposing duties of customs or of excise, shall deal with one subject of taxation only; but laws imposing duties of customs shall deal with duties of customs only, and laws imposing duties of excise shall deal with duties of excise only.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the first paragraph of the section is that a law which imposes taxation cannot contain other measures. If it does, those other measures are invalid. Pursuant to the second paragraph, a law which imposes taxation cannot deal with more than one subject of taxation. If it does, the whole of the bill is invalid. The clear purpose of this section, combined with section 53, which prevents the Senate originating or amending money bills, is to allow the Senate to consider one taxation measure at a time.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, we sought to refer the question of the constitutional validity of this bill, which contained measures including changes to the wholesale sales tax, income tax and fringe benefits tax, to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The fundamental issue was whether any of the measures in the bill amounted to an imposition of taxation. While a range of opinions were presented to the committee on this question, only the government's principal adviser, the Chief General Counsel, expressed the view that there was definitely no imposition of taxation and, therefore, no risk of invalidity. The many submissions to the committee arguing that the bill may be unconstitutional divided broadly into two groups: those arguing that an increase in a rate of taxation amounts to an imposition of taxation, and those arguing that any increase in the incidence of taxation amounts to an imposition.

In the light of these submissions, the committee unanimously concluded that there was a real risk which was significant that the bill, if enacted, would be found by the High Court to be a law imposing taxation within the meaning of section 55. At this point the government backed down and withdrew the bill. Its contents were then reintroduced in the other place in a series of eight new bills. Six of those bills—five dealing with wholesale sales tax and another containing the restructured l-a-w, law, personal income tax cuts—have already been considered. The remaining measures have been put into the two bills which are before us now.

Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 consists of provisions relating to the extension of the fringe benefits tax, which we think will be withdrawn; changes in the income tax payable by credit unions, which we think will be substantially changed, and in the income tax payable on lump sums for unused annual and long service leave; denial of income tax deductions for car parking expenses for self-employed persons; and increases in the Medicare levy for low income thresholds.

Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) 1993 consists of an increase in the rate of fringe benefits tax and an increase in the rate of tax on the life insurance business of friendly societies. The government claims that it has structured the bill in this way as what it refers to as a `test bill' combining two rate increases for different subjects of taxation in order to facilitate a High Court challenge on the issues raised before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

The coalition also received advice indicating that the constitutionality of Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 was doubtful. Both bills were referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Four of the eight members of that committee, three coalition senators and one Democrat senator, came to the conclusion that both bills were of doubtful constitutionality.

In relation to the No. 1 bill, the discussion centred on the new tax regime which is established for credit unions. Clause 41 of the bill removes an exemption which has previously applied to a large proportion of the income of credit unions, and clause 47 specifies a tax rate of 20 per cent for that income.

The government's advisers argued to the committee that this is not an imposition of taxation; in fact, it amounts to a reduction, because the abolition of the exemption results in an liability to pay company tax at the general rate of 33 per cent, which is then reduced to 20 per cent by clause 47.

The other side of the argument was ably put by Mr Tony Morris QC, who pointed out that the effect of clauses 41 and 47 taken together is that credit unions will now be liable to pay income tax at a rate of 20 per cent on income on which they are presently required to pay no tax. He considered that there is a real risk that the High Court would find that this amounts to an imposition of taxation.

All four non-government senators accepted that there was a real chance that a High Court challenge to the validity of the bill may result in this provision being held to amount to an imposition of taxation. The consequence of such a finding would be that the provisions of the bill relating to other subjects of taxation would be struck down.

Further opinions provided to the committee suggested that there was also a risk, albeit a lesser one, that the extension of fringe benefits tax to excess domestic travel allowance may amount to an imposition of taxation. If the argument is accepted that any increase in the incidence of taxation amounts to an imposition, then the application of fringe benefits tax to a fringe benefit which was previously untaxed is an imposition of taxation. If the High Court accepted this argument, then the bill would be totally invalid as it deals with more than one subject of taxation.

In summary, all non-government senators on the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs took the view that there was a real risk that the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993, if challenged, would be found to be either partially or totally invalid. Given the potentially disastrous consequences for the government's revenues of such a decision, the coalition believes that it is irresponsible in the extreme for the government to persist in putting forward legislation of dubious validity.

As far as the coalition is concerned, this also applies to Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) 1993, the so-called test bill. In his second reading speech, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This bill has been deliberately designed to facilitate a challenge in the High Court on the constitutional issues raised before the Senate committee that considered the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill.

The argument put to the committee was that an increase in a rate of taxation may amount to an imposition of taxation. The bill consists of increases in the rates of two different subjects of taxation—fringe benefits tax and income tax. The coalition believes that it is improper practice to deliberately put before the parliament legislation which the government accepts may be unconstitutional. We believe that the bill ought to be put into a form which is unambiguously valid, and dealt with on that basis.

PARA.TAB: Evidence given to the legal and constitutional affairs committee suggests that the drafting time required to break up the No. 1 bill into separate bills each dealing with a different subject of taxation would be minimal—certainly less than a day. Presumably even less time would be required to split the so-called test bill.

I foreshadow that, in relation to bills Nos 1 and 2, I will be moving amendments emphasising that the Senate is of the view that the proposals in the bills ought to have been put forward as separate bills dealing with separate matters of taxation.

The second reading amendment in relation to Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 will also condemn the government for including in the bill a measure which subjects the accrued leave entitlements of Australian workers to retrospective increases in taxation. This amendment will also be pursued at the committee stage.

The coalition is strongly opposed to the retrospective application of the removal of the concessional tax treatment presently applying to lump sum payments for unused annual and long service leave. We were pleased that the government amended the bill in the other place to remove the retrospectivity in relation to lump sum payments for unused long service leave. The amendment to be moved by the coalition seeks to do the same in relation to unused annual leave. Furthermore, in the committee stage the coalition will be moving detailed requests for amendments which will divide the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) into four separate bills and the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) into two separate bills. In relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993, I move:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate:

TAB.TAB: (a)condemns the Government for including in this bill a measure which subjects the accrued leave entitlements of Australian workers to retrospective increases in taxation;
(b)calls on the Government to abandon its proposals to impose retrospective increases in taxation on accrued leave lump sums; and

(c)is of the opinion that the proposals in the bill ought to have been put forward as four separate bills: one dealing with fringe benefits tax, a second dealing with the taxation of accrued leave lump sums, a third dealing with the taxation of credit unions, and a fourth dealing with the medicare threshold".

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) 1993, I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate:

TAB.TAB: (a)notes that the bill is of dubious constitutionality; and
