SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we have before us Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) and Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2). These two bills form part of a package of eight bills which replaced the former Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993.

PARA.TAB: The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) contains the following measures: increases in the Medicare levy for low income thresholds; removal of the concessional treatment that applies to the taxation of unused annual leave and long service leave; changes in the taxation treatment of excess domestic travel allowances and expenses and certain non-deductible expenses—we understand that there will be a government amendment removing the travel component from that; denial of income tax deduction for car parking expenses for self-employed persons; and changes in the tax treatment of credit unions.

In terms of credit unions, the Senate will be aware of a unanimous report by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. It was agreed by the committee that exemption should apply to the very smallest of the credit unions and building societies.

The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) contains provisions which increase the rate of fringe benefits tax in the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 from 48.25 per cent to 48.4 per cent to commence on 1 April 1994. It changes the taxation treatment of friendly societies and increases the rate of tax on their life insurance business, to apply from the 1994-95 income year.

The No. 2 bill is the government's so-called test bill—so-called because it is intended to test the second paragraph of section 55 of the constitution. Although it is obvious to all except the government, the No. 1 bill suffers the same constitutional defect as the No. 2 bill. The No. 2 bill clearly deals with more than one subject of taxation. The government has presented the bill in this form for the stated purpose of inviting a test case before the High Court before any of the provisions come into operation. It is an extraordinary situation that will involve testing the patience of Australian people.

In a budget compromised by the mendacity pursuant to which it was drafted and riddled with economically irresponsible and politically unsaleable measures, it is perhaps bill No. 2 with its dubious constitutional status that represents the highest development of the government's erratic and irrational behaviour over this particular budget. Never before has a government been so irresponsible, so careless of the costs it is imposing on the community, so shabbily desperate to save face politically as to draft a bill that is deliberately unconstitutional. The government should not wonder why people are suspicious about its planned constitutional changes to bring about a republic when it so readily displays such an arrant lack of respect for the constitution.

I would like to deal with the government's behaviour in the drafting of the omnibus bill. The original bill, which has now been split into eight bills, was designed solely with a political although somewhat obscure purpose in mind. The solitary explanation of this strategy came from Senator Evans who stated that the bill's form was for demonstration and presentation purposes or to make clear the connection between tax changes. So, despite even the Tax Office expressing concerns about the constitutional status of the bill and raising its concerns with the Office of Parliamentary Counsel before the drafting stage, the government decided to risk its entire budget being declared unconstitutional, with all the financial chaos associated with such a decision. It is appalling that it made such a decision. The government can scarcely complain about its failures with these budget bills when its behaviour—certainly apparently, if nothing else—has constituted an attempt to do precisely that which section 55 of the constitution was designed to prevent.

If the original omnibus bill was designed to put pressure on the Senate, all it succeeded in doing was to make the government look like a cabal of constitutional vandals. The government, in its confusion, fell between two stools in that, if the bill imposed taxation, section 55 would be breached; if the bill did not impose taxation, section 53 would not apply and the Senate could amend it freely.

I now wish to deal with the purpose of the second paragraph of section 55 of the constitution. I think it is vital when we are looking at any statutory provision, in particular, a constitutional provision, to look at the purpose the provision is intended to serve. Section 55's existence, of course, is explained by first looking at section 53. In the words of Justice Dixon, as he then was:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of Section 55 [is] to protect the Senate from any possible abuse of the restriction placed upon it by Section 53, which provides that the Senate may not amend proposed laws imposing taxation.

The second paragraph of section 53 of the constitution deprives the Senate of the power to amend taxation bills, although it may constitutionally reject them. However, if section 55 contained no other paragraph but its first, the House of Representatives would still be able to exploit the Senate's inability to amend legislation imposing taxation by sending to the Senate a bill containing a number of separate, unrelated taxes.

PARA.TAB: To avoid this, the constitution requires that each proposed tax be contained in a separate bill. In this way, the Senate will maintain its right to examine and possibly veto each specific tax without having to reject taxes of which it approves or disapproves. It was noted with approval at the turn of the century:

SPEECH.PARA: In this respect, the Senate will have greater control over taxation than the House of Lords enjoys.
Mr Justice Dixon went on to cite approvingly the words of Mr Justice Isaacs who eloquently stated:

The prohibition was not inserted as a trap for the Commonwealth legislature and through them the nation. It was intended as a genuine protection to the people of the Commonwealth by guarding the Senate from compulsive acquiescence in one tax by the moral necessity of passing another distinct tax.

It is the endowment of the House of Representatives with the exclusive power to originate money bills and the Senate's deprivation of the power to amend money bills imposing taxation that render this limitation in the hands of the Senate one of the constitutional compromises of a bicameral system.

PARA.TAB: The present High Court has noted with approval Mr Justice Barton's remarks that `the purpose of the second paragraph of section 55 was to prevent the tacking together of tax bills of different kinds in unlimited numbers in one measure'. Further, the court stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The point of insisting on a law imposing taxation dealing with one subject of taxation only was to ensure separate consideration by each House of particular kinds of taxation, and that each would be considered `on its merits' and not just as an element in an overall package
—which the government tried to do in its original measure.

PARA.TAB: I now comment on the result of the breach of section 55. Sir Owen Dixon may have referred to the `hitherto ineffectual menaces' of section 55, but the potential for chaos inherent in its breach should be apparent also to all responsible senators. To understand the consequences of such a breach, it is necessary to date the history of the provision. Clause 55, subclause 3 of the Commonwealth Bill 1891 provided that laws imposing taxation shall deal only with one subject of taxation. These provisions were adopted in the first draft at the Adelaide Constitutional Convention of 1897. The advocates for the change were impressive, including Sir George Reid, our fourth Prime Minister and great free trader, and Sir Isaac Isaacs, later a High Court Justice and Viceroy.

The history of section 55 has a profound bearing on our understanding of the result of a breach of section 55. It contains the reasons why we should be prudent and responsible in dealing with a possible violation of the section. The founding fathers expressly rejected the possibility that such a breach could do anything but invalidate the whole bill—and I emphasise `the whole bill'. They were well aware of the grave consequences of such a penalty but they did not shy away from this severity, believing it to be an essential constitutional protection. The word `proposed' was deliberately omitted with the express intention that absolute nullity would attach to any offending act.
To quote a learned source on the penalty for ignoring section 55:

SPEECH.PARA: The only conclusion is that an Act embodying a plurality of taxes would be absolutely and completely ultra vires.

It is incumbent upon us to treat the prohibition with a seriousness warranted by such dire results. The genesis of this distinction lies in an early judgment of Barton J who, in referring to a land tax assessment act, characterised it as `certainly an act relating to, that is it deals with the imposition of a tax', while going on to say that that did not make it a law imposing taxation.

PARA.TAB: Returning to Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1), its aspects are generally the same as those in the originating Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill, except for a small technical change in the amendment concerning clause 47 of the Income Tax Rates Act. The proposals contained in this bill in many cases have created serious inequity for individual taxpayers and have imposed impossible administrative and financial burdens on business. I refer in particular to the lump sum leave arrangements, the non-deductible expenses changes and the changes to car parking expenses for the self-employed. As noted by the Taxation Institute of Australia in its submission to the government on the original deficit reduction bill:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many of [these] incremental or base broadening measures . . . have been ill thought out and will create further unnecessary complexity to the tax system which is already overburdened with a confusing mass of tax rules that inhibit business and confuse ordinary taxpayers.

The submission continues by noting that the attempt to interrelate fringe benefits tax rules with the new rules designed to limit tax deductions under the Income Tax Assessment Act appear to have been created at a theoretical level without regard to their practical application. In fact, Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu in its media release of 19 August notes that the government has created an entertainment nightmare with regard to the non-deductible expense changes. The proposed changes to the fringe benefits tax legislation contain a number of anomalies in respect of the provision of entertainment to employees by employers which are difficult to interpret and quantify, demonstrating a lack of commonsense and due regard for business practice.

PARA.TAB: Currently, entertainment expenses are both non-tax deductible and not subject to the FBT. But from 1 April 1994, in addition to entertainment, a range of benefits—such as club fees, leisure facilities, travel expenses of accompanying relatives, HECS payments and student financial supplement scheme payments—will be an allowable deduction to employers and, consequently, will subject those benefits to a fringe benefits tax liability. I have received representations from a number of accounting firms and business constituents as to the practical effects of the government's decision to treat non-deductible entertainment involving employees as subject to fringe benefits tax; in fact, the legislation will create all sorts of anomalies.

Firstly, entertainment provided to employees for the firm's benefit will now be more expensive due to the grossing-up effect used in the calculations of the fringe benefits tax. For every $1 spent on the provision of entertainment to employees, the total after-tax cost to the employer will be $1.27—the additional 27c being the grossed-up FBT amount, reduced by virtue of the FBT being allowable as a tax deduction.

Secondly, an issue arises as to the interpretation of whether an entertainment benefit has been provided to an employee. For example, a self-employed person requested one of his employees to attend a business lunch with a client. In the absence of attending the lunch, the employee would probably have purchased sandwiches. Therefore, the employee has received a benefit by attending the business lunch. FBT is therefore payable on the total cost of his portion of the business lunch, while the portion applicable to the client and the self-employed person is non-deductible.

When this situation is viewed on the scale of a large Australian company whose sales force may, for example, purchase some 10,000 lunches for its clients in the course of a year, the burdensome and unnecessary volume of paperwork that will result is ridiculous and shows a complete lack of understanding of business.

It has been estimated that bookkeeping costs, including additional staff to maintain appropriate records and changes to the computer system, may well exceed the FBT payable. As the records are now needed for taxation purposes, they will need to show how much of the costs are related to the employee, which are deductible and subject to the FBT, and how much are related to the client, which are non-deductible. These business lunches are not big affairs. An example which has been cited to me is that they are usually counter meals at a hotel or sandwiches and coffee at a local cafe, with the average cost being about $40 for the entire lunch.

The government's rationale for the change is that corporate entertainment, which is presently non-deductible and not subject to the FBT, is being used to package remuneration in a tax effective manner. If this is the real intention behind the proposed changes, a far more simple and less costly solution could be to make entertainment costs of employees incurred in the course of undertaking their duties as employees non-deductible and not subject to FBT—that is, subject to the existing rule—but to treat other entertainment of employees under the proposed new rules. Thus the government's stated objective could be achieved without imposing significant compliance costs on employers.

Some minor situations may slip through the intended net, but the impact of these on revenue would have to be far less than the compliance costs imposed on business by the current proposal—unless, of course, the real motive behind the government's initiative is to exploit the situation of the $1.27 for each $1 spent.

Fortunately, the government has decided to remove the FBT excess travel allowance provisions from the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) and to introduce—and this is the catch—a separate bill which may gain passage after consultation with industry has been completed. We do not have the amendment, but I have been assured that it will come in later tonight.

Another blow to the businesses of Australia has come with the proposed amendments contained in this bill to tax self-employed persons for the value of car parking benefits. This tax is misconceived in that it discriminates against those self-employed people who own existing car parking facilities. It also misconceives the nature of the FBT regime applying to employees. Employers will just ask their employees to put their cars in the street.

In the case of FBT on car parking spaces made available to employees, the purpose of the impost is to capture the value of otherwise untaxed remuneration benefits. Accepting that the extension of FBT to employee car parking benefits is justified—and this is questionable—it does not follow that there is justification on the grounds of equity to seek to tax an attributed benefit to car parking provided by an employer to himself or herself.

The effect of the measures regarding car parking benefits for the self-employed amounts to a new tax on their imputed value, notwithstanding that it is based on an arbitrary measure—for example, the existence of a commercial car parking station within one kilometre of the business premises. I know of some cases in which half the premises are covered but those on the other side of the road are excluded. It is very arbitrary. The proposed provisions would appear to discriminate against taxpayers who presently incur higher costs associated with the provision of car parking than those taxpayers who have lower costs; for example, when the facility is owned outright. For this reason alone, the proposed provisions do not achieve their stated aim.

The amendments to repeal the concessional treatment of unused annual leave must be questioned on the grounds of equity and fairness. I welcome the government's change of heart to tax concessionally the lump sum component, but I urge it to support the opposition amendment to extend that concession to the annual leave component. The coalition is concerned about the retrospective aspect in particular. The coalition has always upheld the principle that changes in taxation should be prospective and not retrospective. The bill also covers changes to the taxation treatment of credit unions whereby the exemption from income tax for income in the nature of interest received by credit unions on loans made to their members will be removed.

I urge the government to follow the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. We have yet to see the government amendment. Naturally, the opposition will not make up its mind until it sees it. About the only pleasing aspect of this bill, and the one move that the coalition does welcome, is the fact that the government has considered the lower income sections of our society and has increased the Medicare levy thresholds below which these people will not be required to pay the levy. Whilst not declining to give this bill a second reading, I support the amendments that have been moved by my colleague Senator Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) and the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) in order to set the record straight as to the opposition's role in these budget matters. Much has been said to the effect that the coalition has been obstructionist in relation to these budget bills, particularly these two. That is simply not the case, and I wish to set the record straight so that the matter can be cleared up once and for all.

PARA.TAB: On 17 August this year the government introduced its budget. In anyone's language, the legislation came in a novel form; that is, by way of an omnibus bill, the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill, which covered many subjects of taxation. As a result of constitutional queries, on 31 August this year the Senate referred that bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Initially, the committee was to report by 15 September 1993; however, this proved unrealistic and that date was extended to 20 September 1993.

The reporting date was set some five weeks after the budget was introduced—such was the haste and such was the importance that the coalition and this Senate attached to the review of that all-important bill. Of course, it is a matter of record now that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs worked overtime to achieve that reporting date, and indeed it did so. The unanimous decision was that there was a real risk, which was significant, that that proposed legislation could be struck down by the High Court.

The coalition went along with every measure possible to achieve a speedy review of that legislation. We did not unnecessarily hold up that legislation. We did not deliberately put this country at risk, as a lot of people in the press and the government would have us believe. In fact, the reason for the concern about that initial bill was shown in the unanimous decision of that Senate committee. The government realised this, and the result of the government's concern is mirrored in these two bills, one of which the government terms a test bill. The government realises that combining different subjects of taxation, or different impositions of taxation, is unconstitutional and risks invalidity.

The defect was not cured entirely. These two bills were referred to the committee for further advice on 30 September this year. On 5 October this year—only five days later—the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs reported that the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) should be passed and that it would stand the test of constitutional validity. However, this was only by virtue of the chairman exercising his casting vote. By no means was that decision unanimous. In fact, it was uncertain, to say the least. I would venture to say that Senator Spindler, a member of that committee, shared the view of the coalition that this bill risked invalidity. It could be seen to impose taxation on two separate subjects of taxation, as well as dealing with more than one subject of taxation, thereby inviting the disaster of having it struck down should it be enacted.

It is generally conceded that, if enacted, the second bill—which the government agrees was drafted as a test bill—will end up in the High Court. The recommendation of the committee was that it be enacted but, again, that was not a unanimous recommendation. It was a simple majority, with Senator Spindler joining with the government senators. I say that for the record so that not only the Senate but the people of Australia can know that the coalition went along with every effort to have these bills reviewed as quickly as possible. A complete review was done from 17 August this year to 5 October—a space of some seven weeks. In that time, the government took the advice of the Senate standing committee and redrafted its budget legislation. It redrafted it because it knew that there was a potential risk of the whole budget package being struck down by the High Court as invalid.

There is no way in the world that this country of ours will continue to have any credibility in the eyes of the international community, nor in the eyes of its citizens, if crucial budget legislation is struck down. I hope that, in future, I do not have to say, `I told you so' because, if I have to do that, it will not augur well for the country; it will mean that one or both of these bills has been struck down as invalid.

My opposition to these bills is primarily on legal grounds. Crucial financial provisions, such as the collection of taxes, could be subsequently ruled to be unlawful. The wine tax is a fiasco; the government thought it could steamroll the increase in the wine tax through the House of Representatives and the Senate and thereby start collecting increased wine taxes across the country. Of course, we have seen a very different picture, have we not, over the last few weeks? The increase in the wine tax, as proposed by the government, was defeated. That example is perhaps on a much more minor scale because what we are looking at here are more wide ranging bills, more wide ranging measures, which would have a more profound effect on the financial welfare of this country should they be struck down.

As Mr Pat Brazil said at the hearing of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, it would take a half reasonable parliamentary draftsman a short span of time in which to redraft these bills in their proper form. I can see no reason why the government could not have put forward each measure ad seriatim, why it could not cater for each measure respectively, so that the Senate—as was envisaged in the 1890s when our founding fathers drafted the constitution—could consider each measure carefully and responsibly and then decide whether to pass or reject such measures. But, no, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) was hell bent on the stand and deliver approach.

The Treasurer's petulance could be seen by the personal attack he made on the Senate committee. That attack extended to government senators. I can only say that that is indicative of the very personal way in which the Treasurer has approached this matter. It is a very subjective way in which to approach something as crucial as budget legislation when we are dealing with a country of such magnitude with people of such diverse occupations and backgrounds. It is hardly the sort of approach that one would expect from a responsible Treasurer.

As an Australian, I hope that these bills, if enacted, are not struck down. I hope that the fiscal nightmare that I have predicted does not eventuate. For the welfare of this country, I hope that that does not happen. But in a democracy, there are various interest groups who are quite entitled to look after their own interests and their own welfare. No doubt there will be a challenge from among the taxpayers in our community in relation to one or both of these bills, should they be enacted.

This Senate would not be responsible if it were simply to shrug this off and say that there is not much of a risk. In my former practice as a lawyer, if I said to a client that there was a real risk that they would lose the case, they would certainly think again before they took the case on. I am saying to the Senate: think again before we take this case on. We personally do not have anything to lose; it is Australia that has a lot to lose by any successful action in the High Court.

The coalition has done everything possible to facilitate a speedy and responsible review of these budget measures; it has been in no way obstructionist. The coalition still holds to the view that these bills are potentially invalid. I have confined myself to this legal aspect because it will be of great concern to me should these pieces of legislation be struck down by the High Court. I say to the Senate: I hope that we do not have to rue the day that we passed these two bills. I hope that we do not have to look back with regret and say, `Why did we not split them up? Why did we not draft them properly? Why did we not force the matter then?' I ask those who are minded to support these bills to remember those comments.

My opposition is not based on some churlish attitude. It is based on a genuinely held conviction that there is possibly some legal problem with these bills. I say that to the people of Australia and I say it to this Senate. More particularly, I say it to the Treasurer. Unfortunately, having regard to his past responses, it will no doubt fall on deaf ears, although I would like to think that he would put Australia first and think of this matter as a true Australian. There is only one loser should these budget bills be struck down, and that is the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to follow my colleague Senator Ellison in this debate because he has done a fine job of encapsulating many of the concerns which we on this side of the chamber have in relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 and the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) 1993. If one was to look for a title to the tale of these two bills, that title would have to be `Ode to folly' because that is what the form of these two bills is about—the government's fiscal folly. It is about a government that had the opportunity to introduce these tax measures into the parliament in the appropriate fashion but insisted on not doing so.

PARA.TAB: These two bills before the chamber tonight followed the splitting of the original Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill. The government had to be dragged kicking and screaming to split that bill. Eventually a unanimous decision of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs forced it to do that. But, instead of properly splitting that bill, the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, insisted on having what he called a test bill—the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2). This bill sought to lump together two tax measures which on their own are perfectly legal and perfectly valid, but taken together, prima facie, breach section 55 of the constitution, which requires that tax measures deal with only one measure of taxation. That means that we cannot lump them together. The Treasurer insisted on lumping these two measures together solely for the purpose of enabling this matter to be debated at great length and at great expense in the High Court of Australia.

The question we must ask ourselves is: is it necessary for these tax measures to be lumped together in one bill? The answer is no, it is not necessary for these tax measures to be lumped together in one bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spare us and incorporate your speech.

—I know that those on the other side of the chamber do not like listening to the truth about the shambles that their tax legislation has become, but unfortunately Senator Loosley will have to listen to it tonight. I suggest that he stop his interjecting, stop talking to his silly friend and maybe we might be able to get a little common sense into the Labor Party. I know it is a great ask but maybe if he kept quiet a little longer he might learn something.

PARA.TAB: The question I put to this chamber is: is it necessary to lump these two tax measures together? Does the lumping of these two tax measures together make the bill a better bill? As Senator Ellison says, there is no necessity at all. The two measures are totally unconnected—rather like the two neurones that Senator Sherry has; one synapses at one time and the other has a rest.

The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) is an attempt by the Treasurer to try to save some face. He is saying that it is absolutely crucial that this Senate pass a bill which is prima facie unconstitutional so that it can be raced off to the High Court and so we can spend hundreds of thousands of dollars litigating this when for the last 92 years no government has felt the necessity to lump together two measures in this form. What has changed in the last six months?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are adventurous.
—I wish I did not have to repeat myself but Senator Sherry is so slow at comprehending what I am saying that I have to not only repeat myself but also talk very slowly.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is a gross departure from the practice of this parliament and from the practice of good government in this country. There is nothing that has happened in the last six months which requires this parliament to overturn 92 years of established and settled constitutionally acceptable legislation so that the Treasurer can have his day in court—that is what it is about—on a whim and a fancy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the inconvenience?

—And at great inconvenience to the taxpayers, as Senator Watson says. So much for bill No. 2. I genuinely believe that bill No. 1 is not the result of the Treasurer's overweening ego, as bill No. 2 is. Bill No. 1 was a genuine mistake in the way that the government has lumped together with other tax measures a measure which appears to impose taxation on credit unions. I am happy to say that that is probably just a mistake. But, having been pointed out, it ceases to be negligence and starts to become arrogance and contempt when the government could easily amend this bill in the space of less than one day to put it into a constitutionally valid format. The evidence that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs heard was that it would take the Office of Parliamentary Counsel less than one day to split that bill, take out that provision and put it through separately. That is all it would have taken.

PARA.TAB: We were not saying that the government was being arrogant or contemptuous in bringing that bill to us. But we on this side certainly say that, when the egregious mistake has been pointed out to the government, it becomes arrogant and contemptuous when it does not do anything to fix it. It is the government that lectures this Senate about fiscal responsibility. Yet, when it has an opportunity to demonstrate some fiscal responsibility through the practice of good government, do we see it do that? The answer is no.

We are left with only one conclusion—that this government seems to place its own self-importance and its own ego above the good of this country. We have said, `If you bring the bills forward in the proper form, we will deal with them in the proper form', but we do not believe that these bills should receive a second reading because of the form in which they are brought before the parliament. It is as simple as that.

Senator Ellison and I spent many an hour looking at this matter, trying to find any way in which the matter could be resolved. But did the government take the opportunity that was given to it? No, it did not. The government did not take the opportunity that was given to it and so we get to this situation today. We on this side of the chamber have no alternative. We do not believe in sloppy government; we do not believe that second-best is good enough. We believe that there is a way to do this, and this government should heed the advice, at least in relation to bill No. 1, of the coalition senators and Senator Spindler who are all of the view that the imposition of taxation in relation to the credit unions was prima facie unconstitutional when lumped together with those other matters.

That is all that needs to be said. I am sorry to have delayed the Senate. I am sorry that some of the people on the other side could not understand it, but that is the fact. Those are problems that we face with this bill. It is up to the government to do the right thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even in its different form, the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) is an omnibus taxation bill covering many areas of the income tax and fringe benefits tax law. The first one is the Medicare levy increase. It is normal practice to increase the Medicare levy low income threshold at every budget, and that is what we are doing. Thank goodness that for once there is something we are not fighting about.

PARA.TAB: In 1993-94 individuals with taxable incomes of up to $12,688 and couples and sole parents with incomes of up to $21,366 will be exempt from the Medicare levy, although they will be eligible for the full range of Medicare benefits. The Democrats support this measure.

Car parking expenses for the self-employed is another measure that is covered in Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1). We had a very long debate last year in this place on the whole notion of taxing car parking. I think we came to a sensible compromise. Last year, as a result of that debate, car parking provided to employees was made fringe benefits taxable. But, in this budget, the government is bringing in measures to make car parking for the self-employed taxable on a basis comparable to car parking for employees.

We support the equity in bringing the self-employed into line with conditions applying to PAYE taxpayers. But there are some signs that the compliance costs to employers of this tax measure will be great. We are concerned to monitor the impact of this on small business. It always raises the question of whether, when a new tax is introduced, the cost to administer that tax will exceed the cost in revenue and, therefore, whether it will be a less efficient tax.

Changes to the taxation of annual and long service leave lump sums are also covered in this bill. The concessional tax treatment of unused long service leave and annual leave, paid in the form of a lump sum on termination of employment, will be removed except where the termination is a redundancy or invalidity or is under an approved early retirement scheme.

We accept that these changes will ensure that leave payments are taxed no differently if they are received during employment than if they are received upon termination of employment. We believe that these payments are, after all, income. We endorse the move to make the tax provisions consistent.

We are pleased that in our budget negotiations we were able to have the retrospective elements of this tax on long service leave lifted. We point to the anxiety and uncertainty created by retrospectivity. It is one thing to change a measure applying from the date of the budget; it is another thing to seek to change rules that have applied for about 30 years in order to collect some sort of windfall.

Probably the remaining contentious issue is the taxation of credit unions. There are really two strong cases to be made here. The bill removes the exemption from income tax enjoyed by credit unions since 1974. Credit union income to date, in the nature of the interest received on loans to members, has been exempt from tax.

The government is arguing that this initiative will remove the competitive advantage that credit unions enjoy as a result of this tax break. It argues—I think it is true—that it is consistent with the government's general approach on tax neutrality between enterprises. Although they operate on a different commercial basis from that of banks and building societies, it is clear that some of the larger credit unions could be said to be in direct competition with these other financial institutions, particularly in the provision of housing loans and credit card facilities. It is true that the tax exemption on credit unions was never conferred so that they could be more competitive than banks or building societies in these markets.

So, while we understand and acknowledge those arguments, we are concerned about the effect of the tax on the principle of mutuality and on the smaller parish credit unions. That principle of mutuality on its face requires that credit unions provide the socially beneficial services that banks and other financial institutions are much less interested in providing—namely, the less profitable and expensive to administer services, such as personal loans for less than $2,000 and the retention of less profitable branches in rural areas. All around us we can see banks closing in rural areas. A lot of rural Australians are concerned that the removal of this tax exemption will put great pressure on credit unions to follow the example of the banks and remove the remaining service that credit unions provide to rural Australians.

Credit unions are able to operate without charging fees to their clients. They offer low balance accounts for clients in receipt of Department of Social Security payments. Banks are very reluctant to take on social security clients as customers or to give them loans unless they front up with the usual list of assets and liabilities. For $10, one can become a share owner and member of a credit union and secure a very small personal loan or the sorts of services that are just not available from the larger banks and some of the building societies.

The other distinguishing feature is that, when credit unions do the right thing and make a surplus, they use that surplus to provide services that are not available to their members through other financial institutions. For example, they run seminars on the best way to finance, and seek finance for, housing loans. They offer second opinions on the purchase of second-hand cars. They offer travel services. They make a very significant, valuable and alternative contribution to the market. The important point to make is that diversity of financial services is surely to be encouraged, not rubbed out.

The real challenge for the government has been to find a balance to the competing arguments for and against credit unions. I do not necessarily think that the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration came up with the best suggestion, but no doubt we will deal with that when we get to the committee stage.

I will now address the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2). As the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has indicated, this is the test bill which increases rates of taxes on more than one subject of taxation. The passage of this bill will provide an opportunity for the doubts concerning the constitutionality of the original omnibus tax bill to be tested in the High Court. We heard Senator Hill move his declaratory motion. We supported it. It is the view of the Democrats that the constitutionality cloud is best dealt with by the passage of this bill and a subsequent High Court challenge, if that is what a taxpayer wishes to do to test the matter. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs examined the matter. We have heard the outcome of that committee's deliberations and the Senate has acted on that tonight.

The bill involves relatively minor revenue and policy questions. No serious threat to revenue arises if this bill is in an unconstitutional form. The bill also contains the following two measures: an increase in the rate of the fringe benefits tax; and a change in the taxation treatment of friendly societies. The legislation will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 to increase the rate of fringe benefits tax from 48.25 per cent to 48.4 per cent. This restores the rate of fringe benefits tax to the top marginal personal tax rate plus the Medicare levy, following the increases in the Medicare levy on 1 July 1993. This measure will take effect from 1 April 1994, and the Democrats support it.

From the 1994-95 income year, we will see a change in the taxation of friendly societies and other registered organisations. This change will phase out the concessional tax rate for friendly societies in respect of their life insurance and certain other insurance business. In 1994-95, the tax rate will increase to 33 per cent; in 1995-96, it will increase to 36 per cent; and in 1996-97 and subsequent years, it will increase to 39 per cent. In line with this change, friendly societies will be entitled to the same deductions allowed to life insurance companies for the costs incurred in gaining the investment component of life insurance premiums.

Similarly, the rebate applying to the assessable bonuses on life policies issued by friendly societies will increase correspondingly to reflect the changing tax rates paid by friendly societies. The rates of rebate will be 33 per cent, 36 per cent and 39 per cent from 1 July 1995, 1996, 1997 and subsequent years. We have before us these omnibus measures. The fringe benefits tax is awaiting the deliberations of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear).

That persuaded the government of the sincerity of our opposition to this budget. As a result, we have obtained some significant gains. PARA.TAB: If honourable senators would give me the time, I would like to spell it out in this place so that it is on the public record and so that the government has no excuse for saying that it has not made such a commitment. So would those from the opposition mind not interjecting and let me have my say. The $3 a week increase in the jobsearch allowance will start at the same time as the newstart program in March 1994; there will be a $1 per child increase to the family allowance scheme from January 1995, which is preparatory to the second round of increases; there will be a removal of the doubling of HECS for people who take longer than the prescribed time to complete study; and there will be some $2 million in emergency relief for those people who are, through voluntary agencies, requesting assistance.

There are other significant measures that have been gained via Senator Harradine and the Democrats. I will leave them to talk about those. I am simply saying that the position of the WA Greens is such that we welcome the government's taking on board the need to negotiate on a basis that takes into consideration social justice and equity—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your position is an absolute disgrace.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Campbell, would you withdraw that remark, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which remark?

—I said that it a disgraceful, dirty deal they have done.

—I thank Senator Campbell for improving the interjection! The reality is that we feel the signal is clearly there that no longer can a budget be brought down without any negotiation with the industries that feel the impact, and with the type of value bankrupt philosophy that has led to a budget that is a hotchpotch of measures that have been designed for assistance. As it has been pointed out to me on numerous occasions that the Greens have been here only five minutes, I would like to add that, with this budget, we were aware that we had no chance to have input at the time at which it was designed. —The only reason you had an opportunity for this was because of us.

—I am glad the opposition acknowledges that and I am happy to thank the opposition. Without its intransigent stance, we would have had no power at all to negotiate with this government. PARA.TAB: We feel very pleased that we have been able to remove our stand. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp has also wisely interjected. It is the Victorian senators who come behind and support me, not like a few others, whom I will not name.

PARA.TAB: This evening I wish to take up the announcement made today by the government that the 11 November Remembrance Day has been declared an event of national importance—and rightly so. As honourable senators would be aware, on 11 November, some 76 years on, the remains of the unknown soldier will be brought home from the Western Front and laid to rest in the memorial in Canberra. This ceremony will no doubt touch the national soul and remind us that we have shared national experiences which must be remembered and revered on both sides of the chamber.

Up to 40 per cent or more—I believe that to be a conservative figure—of Victorian primary and secondary schools no longer observe the two-minute silence to commemorate Remembrance Day on 11 November, yet this year's 11 November is probably the most significant in the history of our Remembrance Days since the armistice. This is probably the final piece of the Australian identity being laid at a time when our identity is much questioned.
Even the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has acknowledged this in today's paper—and, of course, in today's Senate, translated through one of his ministers—when he was reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I ask all Australians to join the observation of the traditional two-minutes of silence at 11 p.m. on November 11th.

I was very disappointed and saddened to read the comments of the President of the Victorian Principals Federation, Mr Geoff Head, when he said that such observances were difficult to maintain so long after the event. He said:
It's just the passage of time . . . It is not any concerted action by people not to observe it. It just slips away.

It has not slipped away from the memories of the people of France and Belgium. Indeed, along the Western Front and in the villages in Belgium they have played the Last Post in memory of the Australian soldier every single day since the day of armistice; it has not slipped from their memories. This is not a very warm welcome home to this unknown soldier who will represent so many of his fallen friends still unnamed and lying in the ground on the Western Front.

PARA.TAB: I hope Mr Head and those that he represents do not have memories of some other 11 November Remembrance Day, such as the Whitlam sacking; I hope he is not placing that above this particular day. Perhaps not, but he leaves himself open to serious criticism. In particular, Mr Head should realise that Victorian schoolchildren have a very keen interest in Australia's military history. This is shown by the number of requests made to the RSL for school projects alone, initiated by themselves and from their own homes, I am told. The school system cannot afford to overlook the interests of students nor turn its back on the nation's history.

I recommend, at least in my state of Victoria, that the Victorian education minister, Don Hayward, make this year's commemoration compulsory or regulated, or at least give some form of instruction to all headmasters because we can be sure that Mr Head, the President of the Victorian Principals Federation, will not be doing so. The Victorian parliament is very good at legislating and it can whip up a bit of legislation in 24 hours and have it through both houses, so perhaps Mr Don Hayward should legislate it.

This particular 11 November should be remembered and from thence on. It is a most important event. After all, if this country can stop for the three minutes and 18 seconds I believe it takes for the Melbourne Cup, surely it can also stop for the two minutes on 11 November 1993, Remembrance Day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not plan to speak tonight but I was moved to by the comments of my colleague Senator McGauran. I think the events of 11 November, which were mentioned today in the Senate, are enormously important in Australian history—the 75th anniversary of the tragedy of the First World War, a tragedy which marked many Australian families at the time. Indeed, there would barely be a person who cannot hark back to a grandparent or great-grandparent or who would not be able to at least recognise someone who at the time was marked by those particular events.I think it is a pity, as we are at the 75th anniversary, that the commemoration of these events has not been more obvious and public. I am delighted to hear that there will be a special day on 11 November, which Mr Keating has announced.

PARA.TAB: I would like to draw on the thoughts of General Monash. I had the opportunity to read recently General Monash's book entitled Australian Victories in France, 1918. Truly, those events mark one of the great pages of Australian history. Whereas many feature films have been produced by the ABC and other organisations which perhaps unduly tend to attack the institutions of this country, this is really a time when one would have wanted to see some major feature films on the Australian victories in France in 1918.

Anyone who reads General Monash's book cannot but be moved by the enormous achievement of the Australians which culminated, initially, in the push forward on 8 August and which broke through the German lines and destroyed a number of major German divisions at that time. It is surely one of the truly great victories. I think it is a pity that the cultural institutions of this country, of which the ABC is a major one, did not time show the enormous achievement and courage of Australian soldiers at that time, and I hope this oversight will be fixed up on 11 November. Honour and courage do not come naturally to most people. It is a feature of those men and the women of 1914-1918 that they showed not only the great comradeship that is such an important value in Australian culture, but also enormous courage and commitment to their country.

I was a bit surprised today when Senator Collins said that, by the year 2001, maybe Australia will have its own flag. It was an enormously offensive comment to about 99 per cent of Australians and it was astonishing that it came on the day that Senator Faulkner rose in the chamber to announce the special commemorative occasion on 11 November.

The chapter in General Monash's book on the events of 8 August, as the Australian troops pushed forward and broke through the German lines, detailed the reports which came in from the front at that time. There were hourly reports as the Australian troops moved forward. From memory, he recorded that at about 1.15 p.m. the Australian flag was raised over the French village of Harbonnieres. He wrote that he would telex the Governor-General about the great achievements of the Australian soldiers on that day.

Honourable senators can imagine the offence that Senator Collins's comment would have caused to many people. Those men were fighting for their country. They were fighting under a flag which they were proud of—a flag which, as they moved forward and recorded a magnificent victory, was proudly raised over a French village.

I support the thrust of the remarks of my colleague Senator McGauran. I hope that all Australians will remember the previous generations of men and women in this country who served their country so well and so many of them who sacrificed their lives on behalf of this country. I hope the commemorative occasion on 11 November will make up for what I believe has been a fairly lacklustre memorial to the 75th anniversary.

I recognise that the old diggers did go to France, but I wonder how many of our school children know why they went or have any idea of their achievement or what material has been put into the hands of the children. There is time for the government to make sure that the lacklustre approach to these events is made up for. I hope that after the commemorative occasion on 11 November we will be in a position to feel that we have appropriately honoured the enormous achievements of previous generations of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I was invited to launch what I think is a remarkable book, Public Policy, Private Lives. This book is a window into another world. It is a world foreign to most Australians. It is a world inhabited by grief and hardship and struggle; a world inhabited by people whom I believe Australian society is failing.

PARA.TAB: As a politician it disturbs me to see that the central theme of this book is that, while politicians, governments, public servants, the medical profession and the disability service industry all trot out cosy and comforting rhetoric, there is an absolute chasm between that rhetoric and what actually goes on in these people's lives.

The book documents the failed promise of the disability rights movement that got under way in the 1970s and 1980s. It points to the fact that, for all of the talk, a lot of the parents in this situation say that there is an absence of vision, an absence of innovation, an absence of adventurous application of policies that might actually help them. At every turn they find that bureaucracies fall back on the defence that there are just not enough funds to go around. They acknowledge the competition for funds between many worthwhile causes in society.

It is true that funds may be short, but what the parents, particularly the women, whose perspective this book explores, begin to conclude is that they are blocked by bureaucratic inertia, by medical establishment conservatism, by reluctance to embrace new ideas, and by a sense that their problems are just too big and too complex for the system. These parents are left to survive as best they can, and largely on their own.

In reading this book I am moved to ask some questions. Surely the loss suffered by these women and men is enough. Surely a society should be able to step in effectively and intelligently to help lighten the load. Why can we not produce child-care reforms that really help families with disabled children? Why can financial assistance not be better targeted? Why can health care not be prioritised for women who literally break their backs with the physical effort of moving their children as they grow older and heavier or who are driven to the edge of madness? Should we not bite the bullet and honestly and openly question the extent to which medical intervention and costly technology is keeping alive babies who would in previous times never have survived?

I know a lot of the parents involved have the courage to confront this issue. The question is: have the doctors? Why can the medical system not deal with parents like adults and explain all of the options honestly, directly and simply? Where are the programs to help marriages which collapse one after another under the strain of caring for these children? Why is there not a special case made to provide special housing for families that need it? Instead of just talking about the theory of integration in schools, why are education systems still so reluctant? Why are so many schools and teachers still threatened by integration? Why do we keep on applying the bureaucratic jargon of efficiency and cost effectiveness so beloved of the economic rationalists? Why do we not get back to some good old important and traditional precepts like fairness and human rights?

Parents of disabled children spend their lives racked by question and doubt. Every one wrestles daily with the theory that somehow, in some way, some good will come out of their and their child's circumstances. For some, this is a feeble notion. Others remain transfixed by the simple unfairness of their situation.

Along the way, the children and their parents do grow. They meet some extraordinary people with great skills and commitment. They become part of loving, informal support networks. They realise that, however tough they might find their plight to be, there are others suffering more. They learn the true value of the child and they are repaid with great love. And they learn to struggle.

This book has two important achievements. It sets out to link what it calls the `handicapping impact of disability on the individual and the family' with issues of public policy. I think that is lacking in our society and in our parliaments. But the major achievement of this book is to give a voice to people who for too many years have not been heard. The system—and that includes us, as policy makers, especially—must begin to listen.

I congratulate the authors, Dina Bowman and Melanie Virtue, and the National Council on Intellectual Disability, for persevering and publishing this book. The last two paragraphs on page 12, under the heading `The Road Ahead', state:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not present any answers rather we ask questions and point to areas where change is needed. Men need to take more of an active role in caring for the family, career paths need to take into consideration family responsibilities and flexible work arrangements need to be developed, but most importantly good, well-funded and resourced

community support services must be available to support women and men in meeting their family responsibilities. Women in need of support must not be viewed as victims or dependants. Support systems which are flexible, responsive and accountable to women must be developed.

One of the key themes that appears throughout the women's stories is the desire for autonomy and their sense of loss of dignity and control when forced to use services that are provided as a charity. Responsive support systems should not only address the women's need for support, they should also acknowledge their right to self determination. Unless we make fundamental changes to the way in which we structure paid work, community care will continue to be a euphemism for individuals being exploited for their care and concern and the economy will continue to hitchhike on women's sense of duty and capacity for affection.
I think that is a very powerful statement. It is one with which I heartily concur.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 July 1993:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Auditor-General's Report No. 47, released in June 1992, entitled Energy Management of Commonwealth Buildings, in which savings of $29 million to $46 million were identified if the Government used currently available technology and information to implement energy management plans:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question, as far as it relates to my portfolio responsibilities, is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Individual departments and agencies are responsible for efficient energy use in buildings they tenant which may be owned either by the Commonwealth or the private sector. Australian Estate Management (AEM) is responsible for the development and management of Commonwealth owned office buildings. It requires that design standards for all new office buildings and refurbishments must be energy efficient. Associated plant and equipment is regularly serviced and maintained to achieve maximum efficiencies.
AEM has initiated a program of energy audits on all Commonwealth owned office buildings. A large number of buildings have already been audited with the program scheduled for completion in 1993-94.
Energy audits completed to date have given rise to a number of works which are in the process of implementation or have been completed recently.
AEM also co-operates with tenant departments in the conduct of their in-house energy audits in order to maximise the benefits achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian Construction Services has assisted the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in the identification and evaluation of new energy efficient building technologies. PARA.TAB: (2) Successful completion of the trials may result in the wider application of the new technologies to increase building energy efficiency. At this early stage, however, it is not possible to accurately estimate the quantum of savings which may be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to media reports which suggest that Burmese women from refugee camps on the Thailand border are being forced or sold into prostitution in various centres in Thailand
(1) Can the accuracy of these reports be confirmed
(2) What action has the Thai Government taken to eliminate this practice
(3) What is the nature of the Australian Government representations to the Thai Government over this practice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) It is generally accepted that a sizeable number of Burmese women are involved in prostitution in Thailand. Burmese ethnic leaders from the refugee camps in the Thai-Burma border region have told us that women from these camps may have been forced or sold into prostitution in the past, and that they are seeking to prevent this from occurring in the future. There are thirty camps for displaced Burmese people along the Thai-Burma border which accommodate over 72,000 refugees. While the Thai Government has ultimate control over these camps, Burmese ethnic group organisations administer the camps on a day-to-day basis. People are able to enter and leave the camps relatively freely and some of the camps are used as transit points for people leaving Burma to work illegally in Thailand. There have been instances of Thai job brokers entering Burmese refugee camps in Thailand to offer women in the camps jobs in Thailand. Administrators of these camps have reportedly put in place policies to restrict access to the camps to keep out job brokers and campaigns to warn women of the dangers of accepting such job offers.

(2) One of the major priorities of the Thai Government is to address the problem of prostitution, particularly child prostitution, forced prostitution and the sale of women. The Thai Government is currently preparing legislation on the suppression of prostitution which it plans to submit to the Thai Parliament shortly. Thai authorities have undertaken a number of raids on brothels which have resulted in a large number of Burmese women being taken into custody and charged with illegal immigration and deported. Vocational education centres have been set up in some areas of Thailand to provide elementary psychological assistance and vocational training before deportation. The women are also tested for HIV/AIDS and given health advice. The

ANSWER.PARA: Thai Government has appointed a welfare officer to follow up the situation of these women should they return to Thailand following their deportation.

PARA.TAB: (3) The Australian Government has made representations to the Thai Government, including at ministerial level, concerning forced prostitution in Thailand. The Australian Government works with the Thai Government by funding projects designed to assist Burmese women in prostitution in Thailand. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau funds two HIV/AIDS projects which have as a major target group Burmese women in Thailand. An AIDS education program in the south of Thailand targets Burmese commercial sex workers and their clients and involves building up the capacity of the Ministry of Public Health in screening, testing and treatment. Community education, counselling and training also form part of the project. A further project, in the north of Thailand, aims to increase and strengthen outreach prevention and control of HIV/AIDS among commercial sex workers and to mobilise village support groups for the care of those already infected. The Australian Government also contributes funding of $300,000 per year to Burmese refugee camps in Thailand.
